verses.textEn: And he caused a very strong wind to blow from the west, and, seizing the locusts, it cast them into the Red Sea. There remained not so much as one in all the parts of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Qui flare fecit ventum ab occidente vehementissimum, et arreptam locustam proiecit in Mare Rubrum: non remansit ne una quidem in cunctis finibus Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh; neither did he release the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et induravit Dominus cor Pharaonis, nec dimisit filios Israel.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Extend your hand into the sky. And let there be a darkness over the land of Egypt, so dense that they may be able to feel it.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam in cælum: et sint tenebræ super Terram Ægypti tam densæ, ut palpari queant.

verses.textEn: And Moses extended his hand into the sky. And there came a horrible darkness in the entire land of Egypt for three days.
verses.textLa: Extenditque Moyses manum in cælum: et factæ sunt tenebræ horribiles in universa Terra Ægypti tribus diebus.
verses.notes: This historical event was a foreshadowing of the three hours of darkness when Jesus hung upon the Cross.

verses.textEn: No one saw his brother, nor moved himself out of the place where he was. But wherever the sons of Israel were living, there was light.
verses.textLa: Nemo vidit fratrem suum, nec movit se de loco in quo erat: ubicumque autem habitabant filii Israel, lux erat.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron, and he said to them: “Go, sacrifice to the Lord. Only let your sheep and herds remain behind. Your little ones may go with you.”
verses.textLa: Vocavitque Pharao Moysen et Aaron, et dixit eis: Ite, sacrificate Domino: oves tantum vestræ, et armenta remaneant, parvuli vestri eant vobiscum.

verses.textEn: Moses said: “You must also permit us victims and holocausts, which we may offer to the Lord our God.
verses.textLa: Ait Moyses: Hostias quoque et holocausta dabis nobis, quæ offeramus Domino Deo nostro.

verses.textEn: All the flocks shall travel with us. Not one hoof of them shall remain behind. For they are necessary for the worship of the Lord our God, especially since we do not know what ought to be immolated, until we arrive at the very place.”
verses.textLa: Cuncti greges pergent nobiscum: non remanebit ex eis ungula: quæ necessaria sunt in cultum Domini Dei nostri: præsertim cum ignoremus quid debeat immolari, donec ad ipsum locum perveniamus.

verses.textEn: But the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and he was not willing to release them.
verses.textLa: Induravit autem Dominus cor Pharaonis, et noluit dimittere eos.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh said to Moses: “Withdraw from me, and beware that you no longer see my face. On whatever day you will appear in my sight, you shall die.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Pharao ad Moysen: Recede a me, et cave ne ultra videas faciem meam: quocumque die apparueris mihi, morieris.

verses.textEn: Moses responded: “So be it, just as you have said. I will no longer see your face.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Moyses: Ita fiet ut locutus es, non videbo ultra faciem tuam.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “I will touch Pharaoh and Egypt with one more plague, and after these things he will release you, and he will compel you to go out.
verses.textLa: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Adhuc una plaga tangam Pharaonem et Ægyptum, et post hæc dimittet vos, et exire compellet.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you will tell all the people to ask, a man of his friend, and a woman of her neighbor, for vessels of silver and of gold.
verses.textLa: Dices ergo omni plebi ut postulet vir ab amico suo, et mulier a vicina sua vasa argentea et aurea.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord will grant favor to his people in the sight of the Egyptians.” And Moses was a very great man in the land of Egypt, in the sight of the servants of Pharaoh and of all the people.
verses.textLa: Dabit autem Dominus gratiam populo suo coram Ægyptiis. Fuitque Moyses vir magnus valde in Terra Ægypti coram servis Pharaonis, et omni populo.

verses.textEn: And he said: “Thus says the Lord: ‘In the middle of the night I will enter into Egypt.
verses.textLa: Et ait: Hæc dicit Dominus: Media nocte egrediar in Ægyptum:

verses.textEn: And every firstborn in the land of the Egyptians shall die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sits on his throne, even to the firstborn of the handmaid, who is at the millstone, and all the firstborn of the beasts of burden.
verses.textLa: et morietur omne primogenitum in Terra Ægyptiorum, a primogenito Pharaonis qui sedet in solio eius, usque ad primogenitum ancillæ quæ est ad molam, et omnia primogenita iumentorum.

verses.textEn: And there will be a great outcry throughout the entire land of Egypt, such as has not been before, nor ever will be afterward.
verses.textLa: Eritque clamor magnus in universa Terra Ægypti, qualis nec ante fuit, nec postea futurus est.

verses.textEn: But among all the sons of Israel there shall not be even a mutter from a dog, from man, even to cattle, so that you may know how miraculously the Lord divides the Egyptians from Israel.’
verses.textLa: Apud omnes autem filios Israel non mutiet canis ab homine usque ad pecus: ut sciatis quanto miraculo dividat Dominus Ægyptios et Israel.

verses.textEn: And all these, your servants, shall descend to me and shall reverence me, by saying: ‘Depart, you and all the people who are subject to you.’ After these things, we will depart.”
verses.textLa: Descendentque omnes servi tui isti ad me, et adorabunt me, dicentes: Egredere tu, et omnis populus qui subiectus est tibi: post hæc egrediemur.

verses.textEn: And he went out from Pharaoh exceedingly angry. Then the Lord said to Moses: “Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that many signs may be accomplished in the land of Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Et exivit a Pharaone iratus nimis. Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Non audiet vos Pharao ut multa signa fiant in Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Now Moses and Aaron did all the wonders that are written, in the sight of Pharaoh. And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh; neither did he release the sons of Israel from his land.
verses.textLa: Moyses autem et Aaron fecerunt omnia ostenta quæ scripta sunt, coram Pharaone. Et induravit Dominus cor Pharaonis, nec dimisit filios Israel de terra sua.

verses.textEn: The Lord also said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt:
verses.textLa: Dixit quoque Dominus ad Moysen, et Aaron in Terra Ægypti:

verses.textEn: “This month will be for you the beginning of the months. It will be first in the months of the year.
verses.textLa: Mensis iste, vobis principium mensium: primus erit in mensibus anni.

verses.textEn: Speak to the entire assembly of the sons of Israel, and say to them: On the tenth day of this month, let everyone take a lamb, by their families and houses.
verses.textLa: Loquimini ad universum cœtum filiorum Israel, et dicite eis: Decima die mensis huius tollat unusquisque agnum per familias et domos suas.

verses.textEn: But if the number is less than may suffice to be able to consume the lamb, he shall accept his neighbor, who has been joined with his house according to the number of souls that may suffice to be able to eat the lamb.
verses.textLa: Sin autem minor est numerus ut sufficere possit ad vescendum agnum, assumet vicinum suum qui iunctus est domui suæ, iuxta numerum animarum quæ sufficere possunt ad esum agni.

verses.textEn: And it shall be a lamb without blemish, a one year old male. According to this rite, you shall also take a young goat.
verses.textLa: Erit autem agnus absque macula, masculus, anniculus: iuxta quem ritum tolletis et hœdum.

verses.textEn: And you shall keep it until the fourteenth day of this month. And the entire multitude of the sons of Israel shall immolate it toward evening.
verses.textLa: Et servabitis eum usque ad quartam decimam diem mensis huius: immolabitque eum universa multitudo filiorum Israel ad vesperam.

verses.textEn: And they shall take from its blood, and place it on both the door posts and the upper threshold of the houses, in which they will consume it.
verses.textLa: Et sument de sanguine eius, ac ponent super utrumque postem, et in superliminaribus domorum, in quibus comedent illum.
verses.notes: The word ‘superliminaribus’ is translated more literally as ‘upper threshold.’ It can also be translated as ‘lintels’ or ‘upper door posts.’

verses.textEn: And that night they shall eat the flesh, roasted by fire, and unleavened bread with wild lettuce.
verses.textLa: Et edent carnes nocte illa assas igni, et azymos panes cum lactucis agrestibus.

verses.textEn: You shall not consume anything from it raw, nor boiled in water, but only roasted by fire. You shall devour the head with its feet and entrails.
verses.textLa: Non comedetis ex eo crudum quid, nec coctum aqua, sed tantum assum igni: caput cum pedibus eius et intestinis vorabitis.

verses.textEn: Neither shall there remain anything from it until morning. If anything will have been left over, you shall burn it with fire.
verses.textLa: Nec remanebit quidquam ex eo usque mane. si quid residuum fuerit, igne comburetis.

verses.textEn: Now you shall consume it in this way: You shall gird your waist, and you shall have shoes on your feet, holding staves in your hands, and you shall consume it in haste. For it is the Passover (that is, the Crossing) of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Sic autem comedetis illum: Renes vestros accingetis, et calceamenta habebitis in pedibus, tenentes baculos in manibus, et comedetis festinanter: est enim Phase (id est, transitus) Domini.

verses.textEn: And I will cross through the land of Egypt that night, and I will strike down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from man, even to cattle. And I will bring judgments against all the gods of Egypt. I am the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et transibo per Terram Ægypti nocte illa, percutiamque omne primogenitum in Terra Ægypti ab homine usque ad pecus: et in cunctis diis Ægypti faciam iudicia, ego Dominus.

verses.textEn: But the blood will be for you as a sign in the buildings where you will be. And I will see the blood, and I will pass over you. And the plague will not be with you to destroy, when I strike the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Erit autem sanguis vobis in signum in ædibus in quibus eritis: et videbo sanguinem, et transibo vos: nec erit in vobis plaga disperdens quando percussero Terram Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Then you shall have this day as a memorial, and you shall celebrate it as a solemnity to the Lord, in your generations, as an everlasting devotion.
verses.textLa: Habebitis autem hunc diem in monimentum: et celebrabitis eam sollemnem Domino in generationibus vestris cultu sempiterno.

verses.textEn: For seven days, you shall eat unleavened bread. On the first day there shall be no leaven in your houses. Whoever will consume anything leavened, from the first day, even until the seventh day, that soul shall perish from Israel.
verses.textLa: Septem diebus azyma comedetis: in die primo non erit fermentum in domibus vestris: quicumque comederit fermentatum, peribit anima illa de Israel, a primo die usque ad diem septimum.

verses.textEn: The first day shall be holy and solemn, and the seventh day shall be venerated with the same festivity. You shall do no work in these days, except that which pertains to the eating.
verses.textLa: Dies prima erit sancta atque sollemnis, et dies septima eadem festivitate venerabilis: nihil operis facietis in eis, exceptis his, quæ ad vescendum pertinent.

verses.textEn: And you shall observe the feast of unleavened bread. For on this same day, I will lead your army out of the land of Egypt, and you shall keep this day, in your generations, as a perpetual ritual.
verses.textLa: Et observabitis azyma: in eadem enim ipsa die educam exercitum vestrum de Terra Ægypti, et custodietis diem istum in generationes vestras ritu perpetuo.

verses.textEn: In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, toward evening, you shall consume the unleavened bread, until the twenty-first day of the same month, toward evening.
verses.textLa: Primo mense, quartadecima die mensis ad vesperam comedetis azyma usque ad diem vigesimam primam eiusdem mensis ad vesperam.

verses.textEn: For seven days, there shall not be found leaven in your houses. Whoever will eat leaven, his soul will perish from the assembly of Israel, as much with the newcomers as with the natives of the land.
verses.textLa: Septem diebus fermentum non invenietur in domibus vestris: qui comederit fermentatum, peribit anima eius de cœtu Israel, tam de advenis quam de indigenis terræ.

verses.textEn: You shall not consume any leaven. In all your dwelling places, you shall eat unleavened bread.”
verses.textLa: Omne fermentatum non comedetis: in cunctis habitaculis vestris edetis azyma.

verses.textEn: Then Moses called all the elders of the sons of Israel, and he said to them: “Go, taking an animal by your families, and sacrifice the Passover.
verses.textLa: Vocavit autem Moyses omnes seniores filiorum Israel, et dixit ad eos: Ite tollentes animal per familias vestras, et immolate Phase.

verses.textEn: And dip a little bundle of hyssop in the blood which is at the entrance, and sprinkle the upper threshold with it, and both of the door posts. Let none of you go out of the door of his house until morning.
verses.textLa: Fasciculumque hyssopi tingite in sanguine qui est in limine, et aspergite ex eo superliminare, et utrumque postem: nullus vestrum egrediatur ostium domus suæ usque mane.

verses.textEn: For the Lord will cross through, striking the Egyptians. And when he will see the blood on the upper threshold, and on both the door posts, he will pass over the door of the house and not permit the Striker to enter into your houses or to do harm.
verses.textLa: Transibit enim Dominus percutiens Ægyptios: cumque viderit sanguinem in superliminari, et in utroque poste, transcendet ostium domus, et non sinet Percussorem ingredi domos vestras et lædere.

verses.textEn: You shall keep this word as a law for you and for your sons, forever.
verses.textLa: Custodi verbum istud legitimum tibi et filiis tuis usque in æternum.

verses.textEn: And when you have entered into the land that the Lord will give to you, just as he has promised, you shall observe these ceremonies.
verses.textLa: Cumque introieritis terram, quam Dominus daturus est vobis ut pollicitus est, observabitis ceremonias istas.

verses.textEn: And when your sons will say to you, ‘What is the meaning of this religious observance?’
verses.textLa: Et cum dixerint vobis filii vestri: Quæ est ista religio?

verses.textEn: You shall say to them: ‘It is the victim of the crossing of the Lord, when he passed over the houses of the sons of Israel in Egypt, striking the Egyptians, and freeing our houses.’ ” And the people, bowing down, worshipped.
verses.textLa: dicetis eis: Victima transitus Domini est, quando transivit super domos filiorum Israel in Ægypto percutiens Ægyptios, et domos nostras liberans. Incurvatusque populus adoravit.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel, departing, did just as the Lord had instructed Moses and Aaron.
verses.textLa: Et egressi filii Israel fecerunt sicut præceperat Dominus Moysi et Aaron.

verses.textEn: Then it happened, in the middle of the night: the Lord struck down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sits on his throne, even to the firstborn of the captive woman who was in prison, and all the firstborn of the cattle.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem in noctis medio, percussit Dominus omne primogenitum in Terra Ægypti, a primogenito Pharaonis, qui in solio eius sedebat, usque ad primogenitum captivæ quæ erat in carcere, et omne primogenitum iumentorum.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh rose up in the night, and all his servants, and all of Egypt. And there arose a great outcry in Egypt. For there was not a house in which no one lay dead.
verses.textLa: Surrexitque Pharao nocte, et omnes servi eius, cunctaque Ægyptus: et ortus est clamor magnus in Ægypto: neque enim erat domus in qua non iaceret mortuus.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh, calling Moses and Aaron in the night, said: “Rise up and go forth from among my people, you and the sons of Israel. Go, sacrifice to the Lord, just as you say.
verses.textLa: Vocatisque Pharao, Moyse, et Aaron nocte, ait: Surgite et egredimini a populo meo, vos et filii Israel: ite, immolate Domino sicut dicitis.

verses.textEn: Your sheep and herds take along with you, as you requested, and as you go away, bless me.”
verses.textLa: Oves vestras et armenta assumite ut petieratis, et abeuntes benedicite mihi.

verses.textEn: And the Egyptians urged the people to go away from the land quickly, saying, “We will all die.”
verses.textLa: Urgebantque Ægyptii populum de terra exire velociter, dicentes: Omnes moriemur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the people took bread dough before it was leavened. And tying it in their cloaks, they placed it on their shoulders.
verses.textLa: Tulit igitur populus conspersam farinam antequam fermentaretur: et ligans in palliis, posuit super humeros suos.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘conspersam farinam’ refers to flour sprinkled with water, i.e. bread dough that has not risen.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel did just as Moses had instructed. And they petitioned the Egyptians for vessels of silver and of gold, and very many garments.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque filii Israel sicut præceperat Moyses: et petierunt ab Ægyptiis vasa argentea et aurea, vestemque plurimam.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord granted favor to the people in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they bestowed on them. And they despoiled the Egyptians.
verses.textLa: Dominus autem dedit gratiam populo coram Ægyptiis ut commodarent eis: et spoliaverunt Ægyptios.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel set out from Rameses to Soccoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides little ones.
verses.textLa: Profectique sunt filii Israel de Ramesse in Socoth, sexcenta fere millia peditum virorum, absque parvulis.

verses.textEn: But also an innumerable mix of common people ascended with them, sheep and herds and animals of diverse kinds, exceedingly many.
verses.textLa: Sed et vulgus promiscuum innumerabile ascendit cum eis, oves et armenta et animantia diversi generis multa nimis.
verses.notes: The common people were Egyptians, who were amazed by the Hebrews and their leaders, Moses and Aaron. They followed them to Succoth, and to the Red Sea, and many even crossed the Sea with them, as is evident from Numbers, chapter 12. These were the Egyptians and others who listened to the Lord and brought their servants and cattle into the houses, so that they did not die in the hail storm. That is why they had many cattle and why they were willing to follow Moses and his people.

verses.textEn: And they baked the bread, which a little while ago they had taken out of Egypt as dough. And they made unleavened bread baked under ashes. For it was not able to be leavened, with the Egyptians compelling them to leave and not permitting them to cause any delay. Neither did they have occasion to prepare any meat.
verses.textLa: Coxeruntque farinam, quam dudum de Ægypto conspersam tulerant: et fecerunt subcinericios panes azymos: neque enim poterant fermentari cogentibus exire Ægyptiis, et nullam facere sinentibus moram: nec pulmenti quidquam occurrerat præparare.

verses.textEn: Now the habitation of the sons of Israel, while they remained in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years.
verses.textLa: Habitatio autem filiorum Israel qua manserunt in Ægypto, fuit quadringentorum triginta annorum.

verses.textEn: Having been completed, on the same day all the army of the Lord departed from the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Quibus expletis, eadem die egressus est omnis exercitus Domini de Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: This night is a worthy observance of the Lord, when he led them out of the land of Egypt. This all the sons of Israel must observe in their generations.
verses.textLa: Nox ista est observabilis Domini, quando eduxit eos de Terra Ægypti: hanc observare debent omnes filii Israel in generationibus suis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses and to Aaron: “This is the religious observance of the Passover. No foreigner shall eat from it.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron: Hæc est religio Phase: Omnis alienigena non comedet ex eo.

verses.textEn: But every bought servant shall be circumcised, and so he may eat from it.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem servus emptitius circumcidetur, et sic comedet.

verses.textEn: The newcomer and the hired hand shall not eat from it.
verses.textLa: Advena et mercenarius non edent ex eo.

verses.textEn: In one house it shall be eaten; you shall not carry its flesh outside, nor shall you break its bone.
verses.textLa: In una domo comedetur, nec efferetis de carnibus eius foras, nec os illius confringetis.

verses.textEn: The entire assembly of the sons of Israel shall do this.
verses.textLa: Omnis cœtus filiorum Israel faciet illud.

verses.textEn: And if any sojourner will be willing to cross over into your settlement, and to keep the Passover of the Lord, all his males shall first be circumcised, and then he shall celebrate the rite. And he shall be just like a native of the land. But if any man is not circumcised, he shall not eat from it.
verses.textLa: Quod si quis peregrinorum in vestram voluerit transire coloniam, et facere Phase Domini, circumcidetur prius omne masculinum eius, et tunc rite celebrabit: eritque sicut indigena terræ: si quis autem circumcisus non fuerit, non vescetur ex eo.

verses.textEn: The law shall be the same for the native born and for the settler who sojourns with you.”
verses.textLa: Eadem lex erit indigenæ et colono qui peregrinatur apud vos.

verses.textEn: And all the sons of Israel did just as the Lord had instructed Moses and Aaron.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque omnes filii Israel sicut præceperat Dominus Moysi et Aaron.

verses.textEn: And on the same day, the Lord led the sons of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their companies.
verses.textLa: Et eadem die eduxit Dominus filios Israel de terra Ægypti per turmas suas.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Sanctify to me every firstborn which opens the womb among the sons of Israel, as much of men as of cattle. For they are all mine.”
verses.textLa: Sanctifica mihi omne primogenitum quod aperit vulvam in filiis Israel, tam de hominibus quam de iumentis: mea sunt enim omnia.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to the people: “Remember this day, on which you were taken away from Egypt and from the house of servitude. For with a strong hand the Lord has led you away from this place. Thus, you shall eat no leavened bread.
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Mementote diei huius in qua egressi estis de Ægypto et de domo servitutis, quoniam in manu forti eduxit vos Dominus de loco isto: ut non comedatis fermentatum panem.

verses.textEn: Today, you go forth in the month of new grain.
verses.textLa: Hodie egredimini mense novarum frugum.

verses.textEn: And when the Lord has brought you into the land of the Canaanite, and the Hittite, and the Amorite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite, which he swore to your fathers that he would give to you, a land flowing with milk and honey, you will celebrate this manner of sacred rites in this month.
verses.textLa: Cumque introduxerit te Dominus in Terram Chananæi et Hethæi et Amorrhæi et Hevæi et Iebusæi, quam iuravit patribus tuis ut daret tibi, terram fluentem lacte et melle, celebrabis hunc morem sacrorum mense isto.

verses.textEn: For seven days, you shall feed on unleavened bread. And on the seventh day, it will be the solemnity of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Septem diebus vesceris azymis: et in die septimo erit sollemnitas Domini.

verses.textEn: You shall consume unleavened bread for seven days. There shall not be seen anything leavened with you, nor in all your parts.
verses.textLa: Azyma comedetis septem diebus: non apparebit apud te aliquid fermentatum, nec in cunctis finibus tuis.

verses.textEn: And you will explain to your son in that day, saying: ‘This is what the Lord did for me when I was taken away from Egypt.’
verses.textLa: Narrabisque filio tuo in die illo, dicens: Hoc est quod fecit mihi Dominus quando egressus sum de Ægypto.

verses.textEn: And it will be like a sign in your hand and like a memorial before your eyes. And so may the law of the Lord be always in your mouth. For with a strong hand, the Lord led you away from the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Et erit quasi signum in manu tua, et quasi monimentum ante oculos tuos: et ut lex Domini semper sit in ore tuo, in manu enim forti eduxit te Dominus de Ægypto.

verses.textEn: You will keep this observance, at the established time, from day to day.
verses.textLa: Custodies huiuscemodi cultum statuto tempore a diebus in dies.

verses.textEn: And when the Lord has brought you into the land of the Canaanite, just as he swore to you and to your fathers, and when he will give it you,
verses.textLa: Cumque introduxerit te Dominus in Terram Chananæi, sicut iuravit tibi et patribus tuis, et dederit tibi eam:

verses.textEn: then you shall set aside for the Lord all that opens the womb and all that is first to go forth among your cattle. Whatever you will have of the male sex, you shall consecrate to the Lord.
verses.textLa: separabis omne quod aperit vulvam Domino, et quod primitivum est in pecoribus tuis: quidquid habueris masculini sexus, consecrabis Domino.

verses.textEn: The firstborn of a donkey you will exchange for a sheep. And if you will not redeem it, you shall put it to death. But every firstborn of man among your sons, you shall redeem with a price.
verses.textLa: Primogenitum asini mutabis ove: quod si non redemeris, interficies. Omne autem primogenitum hominis de filiis tuis, pretio redimes.

verses.textEn: And when your son will question you tomorrow, saying, ‘What is this?’ you will respond, ‘With a strong hand the Lord led us away from the land of Egypt, from the house of servitude.
verses.textLa: Cumque interrogaverit te filius tuus cras, dicens: Quid est hoc? respondebis ei: In manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de terra Ægypti, de domo servitutis.

verses.textEn: For when Pharaoh had been hardened and was unwilling to release us, the Lord killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of man, even to the firstborn of beasts. For this reason, I immolate to the Lord all of the male sex that opens the womb, and all the firstborn of my sons I redeem.’
verses.textLa: Nam cum induratus esset Pharao, et nollet nos dimittere, occidit Dominus omne primogenitum in Terra Ægypti a primogenito hominis usque ad primogenitum iumentorum: idcirco immolo Domino omne quod aperit vulvam masculini sexus, et omnia primogenita filiorum meorum redimo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it will be like a sign in your hand and like something hanging between your eyes as a remembrance, because with a strong hand the Lord has led us away from Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Erit igitur quasi signum in manu tua, et quasi appensum quid, ob recordationem, inter oculos tuos: eo quod in manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de Ægypto.

verses.textEn: And so, when Pharaoh had sent the people away, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, which is nearby, considering that perhaps they might relapse, if they saw wars rise up against them, and then they might return to Egypt.
verses.textLa: Igitur cum emisisset Pharao populum, non eos duxit Deus per viam Terræ Philisthiim quæ vicina est: reputans ne forte pœniteret eum, si vidisset adversum se bella consurgere, et reverteretur in Ægyptum.

verses.textEn: But he led them around by the way of the desert, which is next to the Red Sea. And so the sons of Israel ascended, armed, out of the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Sed circumduxit per viam deserti, quæ est iuxta Mare Rubrum: et armati ascenderunt filii Israel de Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Also, Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, because he had sworn to the sons of Israel, saying: “God will visit you. Carry my bones away from here with you.”
verses.textLa: Tulit quoque Moyses ossa Ioseph secum: eo quod adiurasset filios Israel, dicens: Visitabit vos Deus, efferte ossa mea hinc vobiscum.

verses.textEn: And setting out from Soccoth, they encamped at Etham, in the most distant parts of the wilderness.
verses.textLa: Profectique de Socoth castrametati sunt in Etham in extremis finibus solitudinis.

verses.textEn: Now the Lord preceded them to show them the way, by day with a pillar of cloud, and by night with a pillar of fire, so that he might be the leader of their journey at both times.
verses.textLa: Dominus autem præcedebat eos ad ostendendam viam per diem in columna nubis, et per noctem in columna ignis: ut dux esset itineris utroque tempore.

verses.textEn: These never failed: a pillar of cloud by day, and a pillar of fire by night, in the sight of the people.
verses.textLa: Numquam defuit columna nubis per diem, nec columna ignis per noctem, coram populo.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutus est autem Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel. Let them turn back and encamp away from the region of Pihahiroth, which is between Migdol and the sea, opposite Baal-zephon. In its sight you shall place your camp, above the sea.
verses.textLa: Loquere filiis Israel: Reversi castrametentur e regione Phihahiroth quæ est inter Magdalum et mare contra Beelsephon: in conspectu eius castra ponetis super mare.

verses.textEn: And Pharaoh will say about the sons of Israel, ‘They have been confined by the land; the desert has enclosed them.’
verses.textLa: Dicturusque est Pharao super filiis Israel: Coarctati sunt in terra, conclusit eos desertum.

verses.textEn: And I will harden his heart, and so he will pursue you. And I will be glorified in Pharaoh, and in all his army. And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” And they did so.
verses.textLa: Et indurabo cor eius, ac persequetur vos: et glorificabor in Pharaone, et in omni exercitu eius. scientque Ægyptii quia ego sum Dominus. Feceruntque ita.

verses.textEn: And it was reported to the king of the Egyptians that the people had fled. And the heart of Pharaoh and of his servants was changed about the people, and they said, “What did we intend to do, so that we released Israel from serving us?”
verses.textLa: Et nunciatum est regi Ægyptiorum quod fugisset populus: immutatumque est cor Pharaonis et servorum eius super populo, et dixerunt: Quid voluimus facere ut dimitteremus Israel, ne serviret nobis?

verses.textEn: Therefore, he harnessed his chariot, and he took all his people with him.
verses.textLa: Iunxit ergo currum, et omnem populum suum assumpsit secum.

verses.textEn: And he took six hundred chosen chariots, and whatever chariots were in Egypt, and also the leaders of the whole army.
verses.textLa: Tulitque sexcentos currus electos, et quidquid in Ægypto curruum fuit: et duces totius exercitus.
verses.notes: Undoubtedly, many of Pharaoh’s horses were killed by the hail and the other plagues. He had six hundred of his own best chariots, and some others that were from various places in Egypt. But before the plagues, certainly the number of chariots that a powerful nation like Egypt could muster would be much greater.

verses.textEn: And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and he pursued the sons of Israel. But they were taken away by an exalted hand.
verses.textLa: Induravitque Dominus cor Pharaonis regis Ægypti, et persecutus est filios Israel: at illi egressi sunt in manu excelsa.

verses.textEn: And when the Egyptians followed the footsteps of those who preceded them, they found them in a camp above the sea. All the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, and the entire army, were in Pihahiroth, opposite Baal-zephon.
verses.textLa: Cumque persequerentur Ægyptii vestigia præcedentium, repererunt eos in castris super mare: omnis equitatus et currus Pharaonis, et universus exercitus erant in Phihahiroth contra Beelsephon.

verses.textEn: And when Pharaoh had drawn near, the sons of Israel, lifting up their eyes, saw the Egyptians behind them. And they were very afraid. And they cried out to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Cumque appropinquasset Pharao, levantes filii Israel oculos, viderunt Ægyptios post se: et timuerunt valde: clamaveruntque ad Dominum,

verses.textEn: And they said to Moses: “Perhaps there were no graves in Egypt, for which reason you took us to die in the wilderness. What is it that you intended to do, in leading us out of Egypt?
verses.textLa: et dixerunt ad Moysen: Forsitan non erant sepulchra in Ægypto, ideo tulisti nos ut moreremur in solitudine: quid hoc facere voluisti, ut educeres nos ex Ægypto?

verses.textEn: Is this not the word that we spoke to you in Egypt, saying: Withdraw from us, so that we may serve the Egyptians? For it was much better to serve them, than to die in the wilderness.”
verses.textLa: Nonne iste est sermo, quem loquebamur ad te in Ægypto, dicentes: Recede a nobis, ut serviamus Ægyptiis? multo enim melius erat servire eis, quam mori in solitudine.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to the people: “Do not be afraid. Stand firm and see the great wonders of the Lord, which he will do today. For the Egyptians, whom you now see, will never again be seen, forever.
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere: state, et videte magnalia Domini quæ facturus est hodie: Ægyptios enim, quos nunc videtis, nequaquam ultra videbitis usque in sempiternum.

verses.textEn: The Lord will fight on your behalf, and you will remain silent.”
verses.textLa: Dominus pugnabit pro vobis, et vos tacebitis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Why cry out to me? Tell the sons of Israel to continue on.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Quid clamas ad me? Loquere filiis Israel ut proficiscantur.

verses.textEn: Now, lift up your staff, and extend your hand over the sea and divide it, so that the sons of Israel may walk through the midst of the sea on dry ground.
verses.textLa: Tu autem eleva virgam tuam, et extende manum tuam super mare, et divide illud: ut gradiantur filii Israel in medio mari per siccum.

verses.textEn: Then I will harden the heart of the Egyptians, so as to pursue you. And I will be glorified in Pharaoh, and in all his army, and in his chariots, and in his horsemen.
verses.textLa: Ego autem indurabo cor Ægyptiorum ut persequantur vos: et glorificabor in Pharaone, et in omni exercitu eius, et in curribus et in equitibus illius.

verses.textEn: And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord, when I will be glorified in Pharaoh, and in his chariots, as well as in his horsemen.”
verses.textLa: Et scient Ægyptii quia ego sum Dominus cum glorificatus fuero in Pharaone, et in curribus atque in equitibus eius.

verses.textEn: And the Angel of God, who preceded the camp of Israel, lifting himself up, went behind them. And the pillar of cloud, together with him, left the front for the rear
verses.textLa: Tollensque se Angelus Dei, qui præcedebat castra Israel, abiit post eos: et cum eo pariter columna nubis, priora dimittens, post tergum

verses.textEn: and stood between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel. And it was a dark cloud, yet it illuminated the night, so that they could not succeed at approaching one another at any time all that night.
verses.textLa: stetit, inter castra Ægyptiorum et castra Israel: et erat nubes tenebrosa, et illuminans noctem, ita ut ad se invicem toto noctis tempore accedere non valerent.

verses.textEn: And when Moses had extended his hand over the sea, the Lord took it away by an intense burning wind, blowing throughout the night, and he turned it into dry ground. And the water was divided.
verses.textLa: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum super mare, abstulit illud Dominus flante vento vehementi et urente tota nocte, et vertit in siccum: divisaque est aqua.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel went in through the midst of the dried sea. For the water was like a wall at their right hand and at their left hand.
verses.textLa: Et ingressi sunt filii Israel per medium sicci maris: erat enim aqua quasi murus a dextra eorum et læva.

verses.textEn: And the Egyptians, pursuing them, went in after them, along with all of the horses of Pharaoh, his chariots and horsemen, through the midst of the sea.
verses.textLa: Persequentesque Ægyptii ingressi sunt post eos, et omnis equitatus Pharaonis, currus eius et equites per medium maris.

verses.textEn: And now the morning watch had arrived, and behold, the Lord, looking down upon the camp of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and of cloud, put to death their army.
verses.textLa: Iamque advenerat vigilia matutina, et ecce respiciens Dominus super castra Ægyptiorum per columnam ignis et nubis, interfecit exercitum eorum:

verses.textEn: And he overturned the wheels of the chariots, and they were carried into the deep. Therefore, the Egyptians said: “Let us flee from Israel. For the Lord fights on their behalf against us.”
verses.textLa: et subvertit rotas curruum, ferebanturque in profundum. Dixerunt ergo Ægyptii: Fugiamus Israelem: Dominus enim pugnat pro eis contra nos.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Extend your hand over the sea, so that the waters may return on the Egyptians, over their chariots and horsemen.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam super mare, ut revertantur aquæ ad Ægyptios super currus et equites eorum.

verses.textEn: And when Moses had extended his hand opposite the sea, it was returned, at first light, to its former place. And the fleeing Egyptians met with the waters, and the Lord immersed them in the midst of the waves.
verses.textLa: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum contra mare, reversum est primo diluculo ad priorem locum: fugientibusque Ægyptiis occurrerunt aquæ, et involvit eos Dominus in mediis fluctibus.

verses.textEn: And the waters were returned, and they covered the chariots and horsemen of the entire army of Pharaoh, who, in following, had entered into the sea. And not so much as one of them was left alive.
verses.textLa: Reversæque sunt aquæ, et operuerunt currus et equites cuncti exercitus Pharaonis, qui sequentes ingressi fuerant mare: nec unus quidem superfuit ex eis.

verses.textEn: But the sons of Israel continued directly through the midst of the dried sea, and the waters were to them like a wall on the right and on the left.
verses.textLa: Filii autem Israel perrexerunt per medium sicci maris, et aquæ eis erant quasi pro muro a dextris et a sinistris:

verses.textEn: And so the Lord freed Israel on that day from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.textLa: liberavitque Dominus in die illa Israel de manu Ægyptiorum.

verses.textEn: And they saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea and the great hand that the Lord had exercised against them. And the people feared the Lord, and they believed in the Lord and in Moses his servant.
verses.textLa: Et viderunt Ægyptios mortuos super littus maris, et manum magnam quam exercuerat Dominus contra eos: timuitque populus Dominum, et crediderunt Domino, et Moysi servo eius.

verses.textEn: Then Moses and the sons of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and they said: “Let us sing to the Lord, for he has been gloriously magnified: the horse and the rider he has cast into the sea.
verses.textLa: Tunc cecinit Moyses et filii Israel carmen hoc Domino, et dixerunt: Cantemus Domino: gloriose enim magnificatus est, equum et ascensorem deiecit in mare.

verses.textEn: The Lord is my strength and my praise, and he has become my salvation. He is my God, and I shall glorify him. He is the God of my father, and I shall exalt him.
verses.textLa: Fortitudo mea, et laus mea Dominus, et factus est mihi in salutem: iste Deus meus, et glorificabo eum: Deus patris mei, et exaltabo eum.

verses.textEn: The Lord is like a fighting man. Almighty is his name.
verses.textLa: Dominus quasi vir pugnator, omnipotens nomen eius.

verses.textEn: The chariots of Pharaoh, and his army, he has cast into the sea; his elect leaders have been submerged in the Red Sea.
verses.textLa: Currus Pharaonis et exercitum eius proiecit in mare: electi principes eius submersi sunt in Mari Rubro.

verses.textEn: The abyss has covered them. They descended into the depths like a stone.
verses.textLa: Abyssi operuerunt eos, descenderunt in profundum quasi lapis.

verses.textEn: Your right hand, O Lord, has been magnified in strength. Your right hand, O Lord, has struck down the enemy.
verses.textLa: Dextera tua Domine magnificata est in fortitudine: dextera tua, Domine, percussit inimicum.

verses.textEn: And in the multitude of your glory you have put down your adversaries. You sent out your wrath, which devoured them like stubble.
verses.textLa: Et in multitudine gloriæ tuæ deposuisti adversarios tuos: misisti iram tuam, quæ devoravit eos sicut stipulam.

verses.textEn: And by the breath of your fury, the waters were gathered together. The flowing waves stood still. The abyss was gathered into the midst of the sea.
verses.textLa: Et in spiritu furoris tui congregatæ sunt aquæ: stetit unda fluens, congregata sunt abyssi in medio mari.

verses.textEn: The enemy said: ‘I will pursue and overtake them. I will divide the spoils. My soul will be filled. I will unsheathe my sword. My hand will put them to death.’
verses.textLa: Dixit inimicus: Persequar et comprehendam, dividam spolia, implebitur anima mea: evaginabo gladium meum, interficiet eos manus mea.

verses.textEn: Your breath blew, and the sea covered them. They were submerged like lead into the mighty waters.
verses.textLa: Flavit spiritus tuus, et operuit eos mare: submersi sunt quasi plumbum in aquis vehementibus.

verses.textEn: Who is like you in strength, O Lord? Who is like you: magnificent in sanctity, terrible and yet praiseworthy, accomplishing miracles?
verses.textLa: Quis similis tui in fortibus Domine? quis similis tui, magnificus in sanctitate, terribilis atque laudabilis, faciens mirabilia?

verses.textEn: You extended your hand, and the earth devoured them.
verses.textLa: Extendisti manum tuam, et devoravit eos terra.

verses.textEn: In your mercy, you have been a leader to the people whom you have redeemed. And in your strength, you have carried them to your holy dwelling place.
verses.textLa: Dux fuisti in misericordia tua populo quem redemisti: et portasti eum in fortitudine tua, ad habitaculum sanctum tuum.
verses.notes: Which place is the ‘holy dwelling place’? It is the Promised Land and it is Mount Zion. The wording of this text indicates that it was written after the Israelites reached the land of Israel.

verses.textEn: Peoples rose up and became angry. Sorrows took hold of the inhabitants of Philistia.
verses.textLa: Ascenderunt populi, et irati sunt: dolores obtinuerunt habitatores Philisthiim.

verses.textEn: Then the leaders of Edom were stirred up, and trembling took hold of the robust of Moab. All the inhabitants of Canaan were petrified.
verses.textLa: Tunc conturbati sunt principes Edom, robustos Moab obtinuit tremor: obriguerunt omnes habitatores Chanaan.

verses.textEn: Let fear and dread fall upon them, by the magnitude of your arm. Let them become immobilized like stone, until your people cross through, O Lord, until this, your people whom you possess, cross through.
verses.textLa: Irruat super eos formido et pavor, in magnitudine brachii tui: fiant immobiles quasi lapis, donec pertranseat populus tuus Domine, donec pertranseat populus tuus iste, quem possedisti.

verses.textEn: You shall lead them in and plant them, on the mountain of your inheritance, in your most firm dwelling place, which you have formed, O Lord, your sanctuary, O Lord, which your hands have made firm.
verses.textLa: Introduces eos, et plantabis in monte hereditatis tuæ, firmissimo habitaculo tuo quod operatus es Domine: sanctuarium tuum Domine, quod firmaverunt manus tuæ.

verses.textEn: The Lord will reign in eternity and beyond.
verses.textLa: Dominus regnabit in æternum et ultra.

verses.textEn: For the rider Pharaoh, with his chariots and horsemen, was brought into the sea. And the Lord brought back upon them the waters of the sea. But the sons of Israel walked across dry ground in its midst.”
verses.textLa: Ingressus est enim eques Pharao cum curribus et equitibus eius in mare: et reduxit super eos Dominus aquas maris: filii autem Israel ambulaverunt per siccum in medio eius.

verses.textEn: And so Miriam, the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took up a timbrel in her hand. And all the women followed her with timbrels and dancing.
verses.textLa: Sumpsit ergo Maria prophetissa, soror Aaron, tympanum in manu sua: egressæque sunt omnes mulieres post eam cum tympanis et choris,

verses.textEn: And she prophesied, saying: “Let us sing to the Lord, for he has been gloriously magnified. The horse and its rider, he has thrown into the sea.”
verses.textLa: quibus præcinebat, dicens: Cantemus Domino, gloriose enim magnificatus est, equum et ascensorem eius deiecit in mare.
verses.notes: The word ‘præcinebat’ refers to predictions or prophecy. Miriam’s song, only the first part of which is given here, was viewed as prophetic. Not all prophecy predicts the future; some prophecy describes past events with prophetic insight.

verses.textEn: Then Moses took Israel from the Red Sea, and they went forth into the desert of Shur. And they wandered for three days through the wilderness, and they found no water.
verses.textLa: Tulit autem Moyses Israel de Mari Rubro, et egressi sunt in desertum Sur: ambulaveruntque tribus diebus per solitudinem, et non inveniebant aquam.

verses.textEn: And they arrived at Marah. They were unable to drink the waters of Marah because they were bitter. Therefore, he also established a name befitting the place, calling it ‘Marah,’ that is, bitterness.
verses.textLa: Et venerunt in Mara, nec poterant bibere aquas de Mara, eo quod essent amaræ: unde et congruum loco nomen imposuit, vocans illum Mara, id est, amaritudinem.

verses.textEn: And the people murmured against Moses, saying: “What shall we drink?”
verses.textLa: Et murmuravit populus contra Moysen, dicens: Quid bibemus?

verses.textEn: So he cried out to the Lord, who showed him a tree. And when he had cast it into the waters, they were turned into sweetness. In that place, he established instructions for him, and also judgments. And he tested him there,
verses.textLa: At ille clamavit ad Dominum, qui ostendit ei lignum: quod cum misisset in aquas, in dulcedinem versæ sunt. Ibi constituit ei præcepta, atque iudicia, et ibi tentavit eum,

verses.textEn: saying: “If you will listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and do what is right in his sight, and obey his commands, and keep all his precepts, I will not bring upon you any of the distress that I imposed on Egypt. For I am the Lord, your healer.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Si audieris vocem Domini Dei tui, et quod rectum est coram eo feceris, et obedieris mandatis eius, custodierisque omnia præcepta illius, cunctum languorem, quem posui in Ægypto, non inducam super te: ego enim Dominus sanator tuus.

verses.textEn: Then the sons of Israel arrived in Elim, where there were twelve fountains of water and seventy palm trees. And they camped next to the waters.
verses.textLa: Venerunt autem in Elim filii Israel, ubi erant duodecim fontes aquarum, et septuaginta palmæ: et castrametati sunt iuxta aquas.

verses.textEn: And they set out from Elim. And the entire multitude of the sons of Israel arrived at the desert of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month, after they departed from the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Profectique sunt de Elim, et venit omnis multitudo filiorum Israel in desertum Sin, quod est inter Elim et Sinai: quintodecimo die mensis secundi, postquam egressi sunt de terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And the entire congregation of the sons of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
verses.textLa: Et murmuravit omnis congregatio filiorum Israel contra Moysen et Aaron in solitudine.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel said to them: “If only we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat around bowls of meat and ate bread until filled. Why have you led us away, into this desert, so that you might kill the entire multitude with famine?”
verses.textLa: Dixeruntque filii Israel ad eos: Utinam mortui essemus per manum Domini in Terra Ægypti, quando sedebamus super ollas carnium, et comedebamus panem in saturitate: cur eduxistis nos in desertum istud, ut occideretis omnem multitudinem fame?

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Behold, I will rain down bread from heaven for you. Let the people go out and collect what is sufficient for each day, so that I may test them, as to whether or not they will walk in my law.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Ecce, ego pluam vobis panes de cælo: egrediatur populus, et colligat quæ sufficiunt per singulos dies: ut tentem eum utrum ambulet in lege mea, an non.

verses.textEn: But on the sixth day, let them prepare what they use for carrying, and let there be double what they were accustomed to collect on a single day.”
verses.textLa: Die autem sexto parent quod inferant: et sit duplum quam colligere solebant per singulos dies.

verses.textEn: And Moses and Aaron said to the sons of Israel: “In the evening, you will know that the Lord has led you away from the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Dixeruntque Moyses et Aaron ad omnes filios Israel: Vespere scietis quod Dominus eduxerit vos de terra Ægypti:

verses.textEn: And in the morning, you will see the glory of the Lord. For he has heard your murmuring against the Lord. But as for us, truly what are we, that you would whisper against us?”
verses.textLa: et mane videbitis gloriam Domini: audivit enim murmur vestrum contra Dominum: nos vero quid sumus, quia mussitastis contra nos?

verses.textEn: And Moses said: “In the evening, the Lord will give you flesh to eat, and in the morning, bread in fullness. For he has heard your murmurings that you have murmured against him. For what are we? Your murmuring is not against us, but against the Lord.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses: Dabit vobis Dominus vespere carnes edere, et mane panes in saturitate: eo quod audierit murmurationes vestras quibus murmurati estis contra eum, nos enim quid sumus? nec contra nos est murmur vestrum, sed contra Dominum.

verses.textEn: Moses also said to Aaron: “Say to the whole congregation of the sons of Israel, ‘Approach before the Lord. For he has heard your murmuring.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dixit quoque Moyses ad Aaron: Dic universæ congregationi filiorum Israel: Accedite coram Domino: audivit enim murmur vestrum.

verses.textEn: And when Aaron spoke to the entire assembly of the sons of Israel, they looked out toward the wilderness. And behold, the glory of the Lord appeared in a cloud.
verses.textLa: Cumque loqueretur Aaron ad omnem cœtum filiorum Israel, respexerunt ad solitudinem: et ecce gloria Domini apparuit in nube.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutus est autem Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I have heard the murmuring of the sons of Israel. Say to them: ‘In the evening, you will eat flesh, and in the morning, you will be filled with bread. And you shall know that I am the Lord your God.’ ”
verses.textLa: Audivi murmurationes filiorum Israel, loquere ad eos: Vespere comedetis carnes, et mane saturabimini panibus: scietisque quod ego sum Dominus Deus vester.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it happened in the evening: quails, rising up, covered the camp. Likewise, in the morning, a dew lay all around the camp.
verses.textLa: Factum est ergo vespere, et ascendens coturnix, cooperuit castra: mane quoque ros iacuit per circuitum castrorum.

verses.textEn: And when it had covered the face of the earth, it appeared, in the wilderness, small and as if crushed with a pestle, similar to hoar-frost on the ground.
verses.textLa: Cumque operuisset superficiem terræ, apparuit in solitudine minutum, et quasi pilo tusum in similitudinem pruinæ super terram.

verses.textEn: When the sons of Israel had seen it, they said one to another: “Manhu?” which means “What is this?” For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them: “This is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat.
verses.textLa: Quod cum vidissent filii Israel, dixerunt ad invicem: Manhu? quod significat: Quid est hoc? ignorabant enim quid esset. Quibus ait Moyses: Iste est panis, quem Dominus dedit vobis ad vescendum.

verses.textEn: This is the word that the Lord has instructed. Let each one collect as much of it as is sufficient to eat. One omer for each head. According to the number of your souls which live in a tent, so will you take of it.”
verses.textLa: Hic est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: Colligat unusquisque ex eo quantum sufficit ad vescendum: gomor per singula capita, iuxta numerum animarum vestrarum quæ habitant in tabernaculo sic tolletis.
verses.notes: An omer is about 2.1 liters of volume.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel did so. And they collected: some more, others less.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque ita filii Israel: et collegerunt, alius plus, alius minus.

verses.textEn: And they measured by the measure of an omer. He who collected more, did not have too much; nor did he who prepared less, find too little. But each one gathered according to what they were able to eat.
verses.textLa: Et mensi sunt ad mensuram gomor: nec qui plus collegerat, habuit amplius: nec qui minus paraverat, reperit minus: sed singuli iuxta id quod edere poterant, congregaverunt.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to them, “Let no one leave any of it behind until morning.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses ad eos: Nullus relinquat ex eo in mane.

verses.textEn: And they did not listen to him, but they left some of it behind until morning, and it began to swarm with worms, and it putrefied. And Moses became angry against them.
verses.textLa: Qui non audierunt eum, sed dimiserunt quidam ex eis usque mane, et scatere cœpit vermibus, atque computruit: et iratus est contra eos Moyses.

verses.textEn: Then each one collected, in the morning, as much as would be sufficient to eat. And after the sun became hot, it melted.
verses.textLa: Colligebant autem mane singuli, quantum sufficere poterat ad vescendum: cumque incaluisset sol, liquefiebat.

verses.textEn: But on the sixth day, they collected a double portion, that is, two omers for each man. Then all the leaders among the multitude came, and they discoursed with Moses.
verses.textLa: In die autem sexta collegerunt cibos duplices, id est, duo gomor per singulos homines: venerunt autem omnes principes multitudinis, et narraverunt Moysi.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “This is what the Lord has spoken: Tomorrow, the rest day of the Sabbath, has been sanctified to the Lord. Whatever would be done, do it now. And whatever would be cooked, cook it now. Then anything that will have been left over, store it until morning.”
verses.textLa: Qui ait eis: Hoc est quod locutus est Dominus: Requies sabbati sanctificata est Domino cras. Quodcumque operandum est, facite: et quæ coquenda sunt coquite: quidquid autem reliquum fuerit, reponite usque in mane.
verses.notes: The addition of the word ‘now’ is justified because the imperative form of the verbs are present tense. The meaning of the verse is to do the work now, the day before the Sabbath, and to cook the food now, so as not to work or cook on the Sabbath.

verses.textEn: And they did just as Moses had instructed, and it did not putrefy, nor were there any worms found in it.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque ita ut præceperat Moyses, et non computruit, neque vermis inventus est in eo.

verses.textEn: And Moses said: “Eat it today, because it is the Sabbath of the Lord. Today it will not be found in the field.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses: Comedite illud hodie, quia sabbatum est Domini: non invenietur hodie in agro.

verses.textEn: Gather for six days. But on the seventh day, it is the Sabbath of the Lord, for which reason it will not be found.”
verses.textLa: Sex diebus colligite: in die autem septimo sabbatum est Domini, idcirco non invenietur.

verses.textEn: And the seventh day arrived. And some of the people, going out to collect it, did not find it.
verses.textLa: Venitque septima dies: et egressi de populo ut colligerent, non invenerunt.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Moses: “How long will you be unwilling to keep my commandments and my law?
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Usquequo non vultis custodire mandata mea, et legem meam?

verses.textEn: See how the Lord has given you the Sabbath, and, because of this, on the sixth day he distributes to you a double portion. Let each one remain with his own, and let no one go forth from his place on the seventh day.”
verses.textLa: Videte quod Dominus dederit vobis sabbatum, et propter hoc die sexta tribuit vobis cibos duplices: maneat unusquisque apud semetipsum: nullus egrediatur de loco suo die septimo.

verses.textEn: And the people kept the Sabbath on the seventh day.
verses.textLa: Et sabbatizavit populus die septimo.

verses.textEn: And the house of Israel called its name ‘Manna.’ It was like white coriander seed, and its taste was like wheat flour with honey.
verses.textLa: Appellavitque domus Israel nomen eius Man: quod erat quasi semen coriandri album, gustusque eius quasi similæ cum melle.

verses.textEn: Then Moses said: “This is the word that the Lord has instructed: Fill an omer of it, and let it be kept for future generations hereafter, so that they may know the bread, with which I nourished you in the wilderness, when you had been led away from the land of Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Moyses: Iste est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: Imple gomor ex eo, et custodiatur in futuras retro generationes: ut noverint panem, quo alui vos in solitudine, quando educti estis de Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to Aaron, “Take one vessel, and put manna into it, as much as an omer is able to hold. And store it in the sight of the Lord, to keep for your generations,
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses ad Aaron: Sume vas unum, et mitte ibi Man, quantum potest capere gomor: et repone coram Domino ad servandum in generationes vestras:

verses.textEn: just as the Lord instructed Moses.” And so, Aaron placed it in the tabernacle, in reserve.
verses.textLa: sicut præcepit Dominus Moysi. Posuitque illud Aaron in tabernaculo reservandum.

verses.textEn: Now the sons of Israel ate manna for forty years, until they arrived in a habitable land. With this food they were nourished, even until they touched the borders of the land of Canaan.
verses.textLa: Filii autem Israel comederunt Man quadraginta annis, donec venirent in terram habitabilem: hoc cibo aliti sunt, usquequo tangerent fines terræ Chanaan.

verses.textEn: Now an omer is a tenth part of an ephah.
verses.textLa: Gomor autem decima pars est ephi.

verses.textEn: And so, the entire multitude of the sons of Israel, having set out from the desert of Sin in stages, according to the word of the Lord, made camp at Rephidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.textLa: Igitur profecta omnis multitudo filiorum Israel de deserto Sin per mansiones suas, iuxta sermonem Domini, castrametati sunt in Raphidim, ubi non erat aqua ad bibendum populo.

verses.textEn: And arguing against Moses, they said, “Give us water, so that we may drink.” And Moses answered them: “Why argue against me? For what reason do you tempt the Lord?”
verses.textLa: Qui iurgatus contra Moysen, ait: Da nobis aquam, ut bibamus. Quibus respondit Moyses: Quid iurgamini contra me? cur tentatis Dominum?

verses.textEn: And so the people were thirsty in that place, due to the scarcity of water, and they murmured against Moses, saying: “Why did you cause us to go out of Egypt, so as to kill us and our children, as well as our cattle, with thirst?”
verses.textLa: Sitivit ergo ibi populus præ aquæ penuria, et murmuravit contra Moysen, dicens: Cur fecisti nos exire de Ægypto, ut occideres nos, et liberos nostros, ac iumenta siti?

verses.textEn: Then Moses cried out to the Lord, saying: “What shall I do with this people? A little while more and they will stone me.”
verses.textLa: Clamavit autem Moyses ad Dominum, dicens: Quid faciam populo huic? adhuc paululum, et lapidabit me.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Go before the people, and take with you some of the elders of Israel. And take in your hand the staff, with which you struck the river, and advance.
verses.textLa: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Antecede populum, et sume tecum de senioribus Israel: et virgam qua percussisti fluvium, tolle in manu tua, et vade.

verses.textEn: Lo, I will stand in that place before you, on the rock of Horeb. And you shall strike the rock, and water will go forth from it, so that the people may drink.” Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel.
verses.textLa: En ego stabo ibi coram te, supra petram Horeb: percutiesque petram, et exibit ex ea aqua, ut bibat populus. Fecit Moyses ita coram senioribus Israel:

verses.textEn: And he called the name of that place ‘Temptation,’ because of the arguing of the sons of Israel, and because they tempted the Lord, saying: “Is the Lord with us, or not?”
verses.textLa: et vocavit nomen loci illius, Tentatio, propter iurgium filiorum Israel, et quia tentaverunt Dominum, dicentes: Est ne Dominus in nobis, an non?

verses.textEn: And Amalek came and fought against Israel at Rephidim.
verses.textLa: Venit autem Amalec, et pugnabat contra Israel in Raphidim.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to Joshua: “Choose men. And when you go out, fight against Amalek. Tomorrow, I will stand at the top of the hill, holding the staff of God in my hand.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses ad Iosue: Elige viros: et egressus, pugna contra Amalec: cras ego stabo in vertice collis, habens virgam Dei in manu mea.

verses.textEn: Joshua did as Moses had spoken, and he fought against Amalek. But Moses and Aaron and Hur ascended to the top of the hill.
verses.textLa: Fecit Iosue ut locutus erat Moyses, et pugnavit contra Amalec: Moyses autem et Aaron, et Hur ascenderunt super verticem collis.

verses.textEn: And when Moses lifted up his hands, Israel prevailed. But when he released them a little while, Amalek overcame.
verses.textLa: Cumque levaret Moyses manus, vincebat Israel: sin autem paululum remisisset, superabat Amalec.

verses.textEn: Then the hands of Moses became heavy. And so, taking a stone, they placed it beneath him, and he sat on it. Then Aaron and Hur sustained his hands from both sides. And it happened that his hands did not tire until the setting of the sun.
verses.textLa: Manus autem Moysi erant graves: sumentes igitur lapidem, posuerunt subter eum, in quo sedit: Aaron autem et Hur sustentabant manus eius ex utraque parte. Et factum est ut manus illius non lassarentur usque ad occasum solis.

verses.textEn: And Joshua put to flight Amalek and his people by the edge of the sword.
verses.textLa: Fugavitque Iosue Amalec, et populum eius in ore gladii.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Write this, as a memorial in a book, and deliver it to the ears of Joshua. For I will wipe away the memory of Amalek from under heaven.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Scribe hoc ob monimentum in libro, et trade auribus Iosue: delebo enim memoriam Amalec sub cælo.

verses.textEn: And Moses built an altar. And he called its name, ‘The Lord, my Exaltation.’ For he said:
verses.textLa: Ædificavitque Moyses altare: et vocavit nomen eius, Dominus exaltatio mea, dicens:

verses.textEn: “The hand of the throne of the Lord, and the war of the Lord, will be against Amalek from generation to generation.”
verses.textLa: Quia manus solii Domini, et bellum Domini erit contra Amalec, a generatione in generationem.

verses.textEn: And when Jethro, the priest of Midian, the kinsman of Moses, had heard all that God had done for Moses, and for his people Israel, and that the Lord had led Israel away from Egypt,
verses.textLa: Cumque audisset Iethro, sacerdos Madian, cognatus Moysi, omnia quæ fecerat Deus Moysi, et Israeli populo suo, et quod eduxisset Dominus Israel de Ægypto:

verses.textEn: he brought Zipporah, the wife of Moses, whom he was to return to him,
verses.textLa: tulit Sephoram uxorem Moysi quam remiserat:

verses.textEn: and her two sons, of whom one was called Gershom, (for his father said, “I have been a newcomer in a foreign land,”)
verses.textLa: et duos filios eius, quorum unus vocabatur Gersam, dicente patre: Advena fui in terra aliena.

verses.textEn: and the other in truth was Eliezer, (“For the God of my father,” he said, “is my helper, and has rescued me from the sword of Pharaoh.”)
verses.textLa: Alter vero Eliezer: Deus enim, ait, patris mei adiutor meus, et eruit me de gladio Pharaonis.

verses.textEn: And so Jethro, the kinsman of Moses, with his sons and his wife, came to Moses in the desert, where he was encamped next to the mountain of God.
verses.textLa: Venit ergo Iethro cognatus Moysi, et filii eius, et uxor eius ad Moysen in desertum, ubi erat castrametatus iuxta montem Dei.

verses.textEn: And he sent word to Moses, saying: “I, Jethro, your kinsman, have come to you, with your wife, and your two sons with her.”
verses.textLa: Et mandavit Moysi, dicens: Ego Iethro cognatus tuus venio ad te, et uxor tua, et duo filii cum ea.

verses.textEn: And going out to meet his kinsman, he reverenced and kissed him. And they saluted each other with peaceful words. And when he had arrived at the tent,
verses.textLa: Qui egressus in occursum cognati sui, adoravit, et osculatus est eum: salutaveruntque se mutuo verbis pacificis. Cumque intrasset tabernaculum,

verses.textEn: Moses explained to his kinsman all that the Lord had done to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians on behalf of Israel, and all the hardships which had befallen them on the journey, and how the Lord had freed them.
verses.textLa: narravit Moyses cognato suo cuncta quæ fecerat Dominus Pharaoni, et Ægyptiis propter Israel: universumque laborem, qui accidisset eis in itinere, et quod liberaverat eos Dominus.

verses.textEn: And Jethro was gladdened over all the good that the Lord had done for Israel, because he had rescued them from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.textLa: Lætatusque est Iethro super omnibus bonis, quæ fecerat Dominus Israeli, eo quod eruisset eum de manu Ægyptiorum,

verses.textEn: And he said: “Blessed is the Lord, who has freed his people from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of Pharaoh; he has rescued his people from the hand of Egypt.
verses.textLa: et ait: Benedictus Dominus, qui liberavit vos de manu Ægyptiorum, et de manu Pharaonis, qui eruit populum suum de manu Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Now I know that the great Lord is above all gods. This is why they acted arrogantly against them.”
verses.textLa: Nunc cognovi, quia magnus Dominus super omnes deos: eo quod superbe egerint contra illos.
verses.notes: The Egyptians, in other words, acted arrogantly against Israel because the God of Israel is above all the other gods. So Jethro is saying that the Egyptians were upset that their slaves had the one true God, while their gods were not true.

verses.textEn: And so Jethro, the kinsman of Moses, offered holocausts and sacrifices to God. And Aaron arrived with all the elders of Israel, in order to eat bread with him in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Obtulit ergo Iethro cognatus Moysi holocausta et hostias Deo: veneruntque Aaron et omnes seniores Israel, ut comederent panem cum eo coram Deo.

verses.textEn: Then, the next day, Moses sat down in order to judge the people, and they stood beside Moses from morning, even until evening.
verses.textLa: Altera autem die sedit Moyses ut iudicaret populum, qui assistebat Moysi a mane usque ad vesperam.

verses.textEn: And when, of course, his kinsman saw all that he did among the people, he said: “What is this that you do among the people? Why do you sit alone, while all the people stand before you, from morning, even until evening?”
verses.textLa: Quod cum vidisset cognatus eius, omnia scilicet quæ agebat in populo, ait: Quid est hoc quod facis in plebe? Cur solus sedes, et omnis populus præstolatur de mane usque ad vesperam?

verses.textEn: And Moses answered him: “The people come to me seeking the verdict of God.
verses.textLa: Cui respondit Moyses: Venit ad me populus quærens sententiam Dei.

verses.textEn: And when any kind of dispute occurs among them, they come to me to judge between them, and to reveal the precepts of God and of his laws.”
verses.textLa: Cumque acciderit eis aliqua disceptatio, veniunt ad me ut iudicem inter eos, et ostendam præcepta Dei, et leges eius.

verses.textEn: But he said, “This is not good, what you are doing.
verses.textLa: At ille: Non bonam, inquit, rem facis:

verses.textEn: You will be consumed by foolish efforts, both you and this people who are with you. The task is beyond your strength; you will not be able bear it alone.
verses.textLa: stulto labore consumeris et tu, et populus iste qui tecum est: ultra vires tuas est negotium, solus illud non poteris sustinere.

verses.textEn: But listen to my words and counsels, and then God will be with you. Be available to the people in that which pertains to God, so as to refer what they say to him,
verses.textLa: Sed audi verba mea atque consilia, et erit Deus tecum. Esto tu populo in his quæ ad Deum pertinent, ut referas quæ dicuntur ad eum:

verses.textEn: and to reveal to the people the ceremonies, and the rituals of worship, and the way by which they should progress, and the work that they should do.
verses.textLa: ostendasque populo ceremonias et ritum colendi, viamque per quam ingredi debeant, et opus quod facere debeant.

verses.textEn: Then provide, from all of the people, men capable and fearing God, in whom there is truth and who hate avarice, and appoint from them tribunes, and leaders of hundreds, and of fifties, and of tens,
verses.textLa: Provide autem de omni plebe viros potentes, et timentes Deum, in quibus sit veritas, et qui oderint avaritiam, et constitue ex eis tribunos, et centuriones, et quinquagenarios, et decanos
verses.notes:
A leader of ten was not a leader over only ten men, but over ten men who were each head of a family. Also, why have a leader over fifty men and also over one hundred? My interpretation is that the leader over 50 was leader over 50 leaders of ten, and the leader over 100 was a leader over 100 leaders of 50. So the ten-leader governed ten men with wives and children, the fifty-leader governed 500 men by governing 50 leaders of 10 (50 x 10), and the hundred-leader governed 50,000 men (100 x 50 x 10).
 Otherwise, there would be too many leaders for Moses to oversee, and too many for him to even find and appoint. There were over 600,000 men (Ex. 38:25) over the age of 20 (most with wives and children). So if a hundred-leader governed only 100 men, then there would be 6,000 of such leaders, plus 12,000 leaders of 50, plus 60,000 leaders of ten men. This approach seems unlikely and unworkable.
 Using the other approach, there would be 12 leaders of one hundred, 1,200 leaders of 50, and 60,000 leaders of ten. This approach is more tenable and more practical. Also, the tribunes were not leaders over a thousand, but were like a court of appeals, to avoid unfairness or arbitrary judgments by the leaders. The tribunes governed the other leaders.

verses.textEn: who may judge the people at all times. Then, when anything greater will have occurred, they may refer it to you, and let them judge the lesser matters only. And so it may be lighter for you, the burden being divided among others.
verses.textLa: qui iudicent populum omni tempore: quidquid autem maius fuerit, referant ad te, et ipsi minora tantummodo iudicent: leviusque sit tibi, partito in alios onere.

verses.textEn: If you will do this, you will fulfill the orders of God, and you will be able to uphold his precepts. And this entire people will return to their places in peace.”
verses.textLa: Si hoc feceris, implebis imperium Dei, et præcepta eius poteris sustentare: et omnis hic populus revertetur ad loca sua cum pace.

verses.textEn: Having heard this, Moses did everything that he had suggested to him.
verses.textLa: Quibus auditis, Moyses fecit omnia quæ ille suggesserat.

verses.textEn: And choosing virtuous men from all of Israel, he appointed them as leaders of the people: tribunes, and leaders of hundreds, and of fifties, and of tens.
verses.textLa: Et electis viris strenuis de cuncto Israel, constituit eos principes populi, tribunos, et centuriones, et quinquagenarios, et decanos.

verses.textEn: And they judged the people at all times. But whatever was more serious, they referred to him, and they judged easier matters only.
verses.textLa: Qui iudicabant plebem omni tempore: quidquid autem gravius erat, referebant ad eum, faciliora tantummodo iudicantes.

verses.textEn: And he dismissed his kinsman, who, turning back, went to his own land.
verses.textLa: Dimisitque cognatum suum: qui reversus abiit in terram suam.

verses.textEn: In the third month of the departure of Israel from the land of Egypt, in that day, they arrived in the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.textLa: Mense tertio egressionis Israel de Terra Ægypti, in die hac venerunt in solitudinem Sinai.

verses.textEn: Thus, setting out from Raphidim, and going directly to the desert of Sinai, they encamped in the same place, and there Israel pitched their tents away from the region of the mountain.
verses.textLa: Nam profecti de Raphidim, et pervenientes usque in desertum Sinai, castrametati sunt in eodem loco, ibique Israel fixit tentoria e regione montis.

verses.textEn: Then Moses ascended to God. And the Lord called to him from the mountain, and he said: “This you shall say to the house of Jacob, and announce to the sons of Israel:
verses.textLa: Moyses autem ascendit ad Deum, vocavitque eum Dominus de monte, et ait: Hæc dices domui Iacob, et annunciabis filiis Israel:

verses.textEn: ‘You have seen what I have done to the Egyptians, in what way I carried you upon the wings of eagles and how I have taken you for myself.
verses.textLa: Vos ipsi vidistis, quæ fecerim Ægyptiis, quo modo portaverim vos super alas aquilarum, et assumpserim mihi.

verses.textEn: If, therefore, you will hear my voice, and you will keep my covenant, you will be to me a particular possession out of all people. For all the earth is mine.
verses.textLa: Si ergo audieritis vocem meam, et custodieritis pactum meum, eritis mihi in peculium de cunctis populis: mea est enim omnis terra.

verses.textEn: And you will be to me a priestly kingdom and a holy nation.’ These are the words that you will speak to the sons of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Et vos eritis mihi in regnum sacerdotale, et gens sancta. Hæc sunt verba quæ loqueris ad filios Israel.

verses.textEn: Moses went, and calling together those greater by birth among the people, he set forth all the words which the Lord had commanded.
verses.textLa: Venit Moyses: et convocatis maioribus natu populi, exposuit omnes sermones quos mandaverat Dominus.

verses.textEn: And all the people responded together: “Everything that the Lord has spoken, we shall do.” And when Moses had related the words of the people to the Lord,
verses.textLa: Responditque omnis populus simul: Cuncta quæ locutus est Dominus, faciemus. Cumque retulisset Moyses verba populi ad Dominum,

verses.textEn: the Lord said to him: “Soon now, I will come to you in the mist of a cloud, so that the people may hear me speaking to you, and so that they may believe you continuously.” Therefore, Moses reported the words of the people to the Lord,
verses.textLa: ait ei Dominus: Iam nunc veniam ad te in caligine nubis, ut audiat me populus loquentem ad te, et credat tibi in perpetuum. Nunciavit ergo Moyses verba populi ad Dominum.

verses.textEn: who said to him: “Go to the people, and sanctify them today, and tomorrow, and let them wash their garments.
verses.textLa: Qui dixit ei: Vade ad populum, et sanctifica illos hodie, et cras, laventque vestimenta sua.

verses.textEn: And let them be prepared on the third day. For on the third day, the Lord will descend, in the sight of all the people, over Mount Sinai.
verses.textLa: Et sint parati in diem tertium: in die enim tertia descendet Dominus coram omni plebe super montem Sinai.

verses.textEn: And you will establish limits for the people all around, and you will say to them: ‘Take care not to ascend to the mountain, and that you do not touch its parts. All who touch the mountain, shall die a death.’
verses.textLa: Constituesque terminos populo per circuitum, et dices ad eos: Cavete ne ascendatis in montem, nec tangatis fines illius: omnis qui tetigerit montem, morte morietur.

verses.textEn: Hands shall not touch him, but he shall be crushed with stones, or he shall be pierced through with darts. Whether it be a beast or a man, he shall not live. For when the trumpet begins to sound, perhaps they might go up toward the mountain.”
verses.textLa: Manus non tanget eum, sed lapidibus opprimetur, aut confodietur iaculis: sive iumentum fuerit, sive homo, non vivet. Cum cœperit clangere buccina, tunc ascendant in montem.
verses.notes: Verse 12 has an order prohibiting the people from ascending the mountain under pain of death. Verse 13 is sometimes translated as if the sounding of the trumpet permits them to ascend. (Only on the last day, at the time of the general resurrection, does the sounding of the trumpet permit the faithful to ascend to God.) But, in the context of ancient times at Mount Sinai, the translation is that the sounding of the trumpet (and the other signs that cause the people to wonder) might cause them to ascend, i.e. out of curiosity and against God’s orders.

verses.textEn: And Moses came down from the mountain to the people, and he sanctified them. And when they had washed their garments,
verses.textLa: Descenditque Moyses de monte ad populum, et sanctificavit eum. Cumque lavissent vestimenta sua,

verses.textEn: he said to them, “Be prepared on the third day, and do not draw near to your wives.”
verses.textLa: ait ad eos: Estote parati in diem tertium, et ne appropinquetis uxoribus vestris.
verses.notes: The word ‘appropinquetis’ is here used as a euphemism, referring to marital relations.

verses.textEn: And now, the third day arrived and the morning dawned. And behold, thunders began to be heard, and also lightning flashed, and a very dense cloud covered the mountain, and the noise of the trumpet resounded vehemently. And the people who were in the camp were fearful.
verses.textLa: Iamque advenerat tertius dies, et mane inclaruerat: et ecce cœperunt audiri tonitrua, ac micare fulgura, et nubes densissima operire montem, clangorque buccinæ vehementius perstrepebat: et timuit populus qui erat in castris.

verses.textEn: And when Moses had led them out to meet God, from the place of the camp, they stood at the base of the mountain.
verses.textLa: Cumque eduxisset eos Moyses in occursum Dei de loco castrorum, steterunt ad radices montis.

verses.textEn: Then all of Mount Sinai was smoking. For the Lord had descended over it with fire, and smoke ascended from it, as from a furnace. And the entire mountain was terrible.
