verses.textLa: Totus autem mons Sinai fumabat: eo quod descendisset Dominus super eum in igne, et ascenderet fumus ex eo quasi de fornace: eratque omnis mons terribilis.

verses.textEn: And the sound of the trumpet gradually increased to be louder, and extended to be longer. Moses was speaking, and God was answering him.
verses.textLa: Et sonitus buccinæ paulatim crescebat in maius, et prolixius tendebatur: Moyses loquebatur, et Deus respondebat ei.

verses.textEn: And the Lord descended over Mount Sinai, to the very top of the mountain, and he called Moses to its summit. And when he had ascended there,
verses.textLa: Descenditque Dominus super montem Sinai in ipso montis vertice, et vocavit Moysen in cacumen eius. Quo cum ascendisset,

verses.textEn: he said to him: “Descend, and call the people to witness, lest they might be willing to transgress the limits, so as to see the Lord, and a very great multitude of them might perish.
verses.textLa: dixit ad eum: Descende, et contestare populum: ne forte velit transcendere terminos ad videndum Dominum, et pereat ex eis plurima multitudo.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the priests who approach toward the Lord, let them be sanctified, lest he strike them down.”
verses.textLa: Sacerdotes quoque qui accedunt ad Dominum, sanctificentur, ne percutiat eos.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to the Lord: “The people are not able to ascend to Mount Sinai. For you testified, and you commanded, saying: ‘Set limits around the mountain, and sanctify it.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses ad Dominum: Non poterit vulgus ascendere in montem Sinai: tu enim testificatus es, et iussisti, dicens: Pone terminos circa montem, et sanctifica illum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him, “Go, descend. And you shall ascend, and Aaron with you. But let not the priests or the people transgress the limits, nor ascend to the Lord, lest perhaps he may put them to death.”
verses.textLa: Cui ait Dominus: Vade, descende: ascendesque tu, et Aaron tecum: sacerdotes autem et populus ne transeant terminos, nec ascendant ad Dominum, ne forte interficiat illos.

verses.textEn: And Moses descended to the people, and he explained everything to them.
verses.textLa: Descenditque Moyses ad populum, et omnia narravit eis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke all these words:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus cunctos sermones hos:

verses.textEn: “I am the Lord your God, who led you away from the land of Egypt, out of the house of servitude.
verses.textLa: Ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, qui eduxi te de Terra Ægypti, de domo servitutis.

verses.textEn: You shall not have strange gods before me.
verses.textLa: Non habebis deos alienos coram me.

verses.textEn: You shall not make for yourself a graven image, nor a likeness of anything that is in heaven above or on earth below, nor of those things which are in the waters under the earth.
verses.textLa: Non facies tibi sculptile, neque omnem similitudinem quæ est in cælo desuper, et quæ in terra deorsum, nec eorum quæ sunt in aquis sub terra.

verses.textEn: You shall not adore them, nor shall you worship them. I am the Lord your God: strong, zealous, visiting the iniquity of the fathers on the sons to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me,
verses.textLa: Non adorabis ea, neque coles: ego sum Dominus Deus tuus fortis, zelotes, visitans iniquitatem patrum in filios, in tertiam et quartam generationem eorum qui oderunt me:

verses.textEn: and showing mercy to thousands of those who love me and keep my precepts.
verses.textLa: et faciens misericordiam in millia his qui diligunt me, et custodiunt præcepta mea.

verses.textEn: You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain. For the Lord will not hold harmless one who takes the name of the Lord his God falsely.
verses.textLa: Non assumes nomen Domini Dei tui in vanum. Nec enim habebit insontem Dominus eum qui assumpserit nomen Domini Dei sui frustra.

verses.textEn: Remember that you are to sanctify the day of the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Memento ut diem Sabbati sanctifices.

verses.textEn: For six days, you will work and accomplish all your tasks.
verses.textLa: Sex diebus operaberis, et facies omnia opera tua.

verses.textEn: But the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord your God. You shall not do any work in it: you and your son and your daughter, your male servant and your female servant, your beast and the newcomer who is within your gates.
verses.textLa: Septimo autem die Sabbatum Domini Dei tui est: non facies omne opus in eo, tu, et filius tuus et filia tua, servus tuus et ancilla tua, iumentum tuum, et advena qui est intra portas tuas.

verses.textEn: For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, and the sea, and all the things that are in them, and so he rested on the seventh day. For this reason, the Lord has blessed the day of the Sabbath and sanctified it.
verses.textLa: Sex enim diebus fecit Dominus cælum et terram, et mare, et omnia quæ in eis sunt, et requievit in die septimo, idcirco benedixit Dominus diei Sabbati, et sanctificavit eum.

verses.textEn: Honor your father and your mother, so that you may have a long life upon the land, which the Lord your God will give to you.
verses.textLa: Honora patrem tuum et matrem tuam, ut sis longævus super terram, quam Dominus Deus tuus dabit tibi.

verses.textEn: You shall not murder.
verses.textLa: Non occides.
verses.notes: The word ‘occides’ can refer to killing, or more specifically to murdering. The ideal is to have a society where there is no killing at all (even without killing in war, or in law enforcement, or in self-defense), but the minimum requirement of the commandment is not to murder.

verses.textEn: You shall not commit adultery.
verses.textLa: Non mœchaberis.

verses.textEn: You shall not steal.
verses.textLa: Non furtum facies.

verses.textEn: You shall not speak false testimony against your neighbor.
verses.textLa: Non loqueris contra proximum tuum falsum testimonium.

verses.textEn: You shall not covet the house of your neighbor; neither shall you desire his wife, nor male servant, nor female servant, nor ox, nor donkey, nor anything that is his.”
verses.textLa: Non concupisces domum proximi tui: nec desiderabis uxorem eius, non servum, non ancillam, non bovem, non asinum, nec omnia quæ illius sunt.

verses.textEn: Then all the people considered the voices, and the lights, and the sound of the trumpet, and the smoking mountain. And being terrified and struck with fear, they stood at a distance,
verses.textLa: Cunctus autem populus videbat voces et lampades, et sonitum buccinæ, montemque fumantem: et perterriti ac pavore concussi, steterunt procul,

verses.textEn: saying to Moses: “Speak to us, and we will listen. Let not the Lord speak to us, lest perhaps we may die.”
verses.textLa: dicentes Moysi: Loquere tu nobis, et audiemus: non loquatur nobis Dominus, ne forte moriamur.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to the people: “Do not be afraid. For God came in order to test you, and so that the dread of him might be with you, and you would not sin.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere: ut enim probaret vos venit Deus, et ut terror illius esset in vobis, et non peccaretis.

verses.textEn: And the people stood far away. But Moses approached toward the mist, in which was God.
verses.textLa: Stetitque populus de longe. Moyses autem accessit ad caliginem in qua erat Deus.

verses.textEn: Thereafter, the Lord said to Moses: “This you shall say to the sons of Israel: You have seen that I have spoken to you from heaven.
verses.textLa: Dixit præterea Dominus ad Moysen: Hæc dices filiis Israel: Vos vidistis quod de cælo locutus sim vobis.

verses.textEn: You shall not make gods of silver, nor shall you make for yourselves gods of gold.
verses.textLa: Non facietis deos argenteos, nec deos aureos facietis vobis.

verses.textEn: You shall make an altar from the earth for me, and you shall offer upon it your holocausts and peace-offerings, your sheep and oxen, in every place where the memory of my name shall be. I will come to you, and I will bless you.
verses.textLa: Altare de terra facietis mihi, et offeretis super eo holocausta et pacifica vestra, oves vestras et boves in omni loco in quo memoria fuerit nominis mei: veniam ad te, et benedicam tibi.

verses.textEn: And if you make an altar of stone for me, you shall not build it from cut stones; for if you lift up a tool over it, it will be defiled.
verses.textLa: Quod si altare lapideum feceris mihi, non ædificabis illud de sectis lapidibus: si enim levaveris cultrum super eo, polluetur.

verses.textEn: You shall not ascend by steps to my altar, lest your nakedness be revealed.”
verses.textLa: Non ascendes per gradus ad altare meum, ne reveletur turpitudo tua.

verses.textEn: “These are the judgments which you shall place before them:
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt iudicia quæ propones eis.

verses.textEn: If you buy a Hebrew servant, six years shall he serve you; in the seventh, he shall depart freely, without charge.
verses.textLa: Si emeris servum Hebræum, sex annis serviet tibi: in septimo egredietur liber gratis.

verses.textEn: With whatever clothing he arrived, with the like let him depart. If he has a wife, his wife also shall depart, at the same time.
verses.textLa: Cum quali veste intraverit, cum tali exeat: si habens uxorem, et uxor egredietur simul.

verses.textEn: But if his lord gave him a wife, and she has borne sons and daughters, the woman and her children shall belong to her lord. Yet still, he himself will go out with his clothing.
verses.textLa: Sin autem dominus dederit illi uxorem, et pepererit filios et filias: mulier et liberi eius erunt domini sui, ipse vero exibit cum vestitu suo.

verses.textEn: And if the servant will say, ‘I love my lord, and my wife and children, I will not depart freely,’
verses.textLa: Quod si dixerit servus: Diligo dominum meum et uxorem ac liberos, non egrediar liber:

verses.textEn: then his lord shall make an offering for him to the heavens, and it shall be applied to the door and the posts, and he will pierce his ear with an awl. And he shall be his servant in perpetuity.
verses.textLa: offeret eum dominus diis, et applicabitur ad ostium et postes, perforabitque aurem eius subula: et erit ei servus in sæculum.
verses.notes: This verse is translated somewhat more loosely, so that the meaning is clearer. The master of the household makes an offering (animal sacrifice) on behalf of his servant, then he applies some of its blood (in the manner of the Passover) to the door posts. The offering cannot be understood as to ‘the gods’ because the previous verses forbid sacrifices to other gods. The word ‘diis’ has a broader meaning than the word ‘gods.’ It refers to things that are divine, i.e. to the heavens.

verses.textEn: If anyone sells his daughter to be a servant, she shall not depart as a female servant is accustomed to go out.
verses.textLa: Si quis vendiderit filiam suam in famulam, non egredietur sicut ancillæ exire consueverunt.

verses.textEn: If she displeases the eyes of her lord, to whom she had been delivered, he shall dismiss her. But he shall have no authority to sell her to a foreign people, even if he despises her.
verses.textLa: Si displicuerit oculis domini sui cui tradita fuerat, dimittet eam: populo autem alieno vendendi non habebit potestatem, si spreverit eam.

verses.textEn: But if he has betrothed her to his son, he shall treat her according to the custom with daughters.
verses.textLa: Sin autem filio suo desponderit eam, iuxta morem filiarum faciet illi.

verses.textEn: And if he takes another for him, he shall provide to the maiden a marriage, and clothing, and he shall not refuse the price of her chastity.
verses.textLa: Quod si alteram ei acceperit, providebit puellæ nuptias, et vestimenta, et pretium pudicitiæ non negabit.

verses.textEn: If he does not do these three things, she shall depart freely, without money.
verses.textLa: Si tria ista non fecerit, egredietur gratis absque pecunia.

verses.textEn: Whoever strikes a man, intending to murder, shall be put to death.
verses.textLa: Qui percusserit hominem volens occidere, morte moriatur.
verses.notes: Or, more literally: ‘shall die a death.’

verses.textEn: But if he did not lie in wait for him, but God delivered him into his hands, then I will appoint for you a place to which he must flee.
verses.textLa: Qui autem non est insidiatus, sed Deus illum tradidit in manus eius: constituam tibi locum in quem fugere debeat.

verses.textEn: If someone murders his neighbor with deliberation, by lying in wait, you shall tear him away from my altar, so that he may die.
verses.textLa: Si quis per industriam occiderit proximum suum, et per insidias: ab altari meo evelles eum, ut moriatur.

verses.textEn: Whoever strikes his father or mother shall die a death.
verses.textLa: Qui percusserit patrem suum aut matrem, morte moriatur.

verses.textEn: Whoever will have stolen a man and sold him, having been convicted of the crime, shall be put to death.
verses.textLa: Qui furatus fuerit hominem, et vendiderit eum, convictus noxæ, morte moriatur.

verses.textEn: Whoever speaks evil of his father or mother shall die a death.
verses.textLa: Qui maledixerit patri suo, vel matri, morte moriatur.

verses.textEn: If men will have quarreled, and one of them has struck his neighbor with a stone or a fist, and he does not die, but lies in bed,
verses.textLa: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit alter proximum suum lapide vel pugno, et ille mortuus non fuerit, sed iacuerit in lectulo:

verses.textEn: if he gets up again and can walk outside on his staff, he who struck him will be innocent, but only if he makes sufficient restitution for his deeds and for the cost of the physicians.
verses.textLa: si surrexerit, et ambulaverit foris super baculum suum, innocens erit qui percusserit, ita tamen ut operas eius, et impensas in medicos restituat.

verses.textEn: Whoever strikes his male or female servant with a staff, and if they have died by his hands, he shall be guilty of a crime.
verses.textLa: Qui percusserit servum suum, vel ancillam virga, et mortui fuerint in manibus eius, criminis reus erit.

verses.textEn: But if he survives for one day or two, he shall not be subject to punishment, because it is his money.
verses.textLa: Sin autem uno die vel duobus supervixerit, non subiacebit pœnæ, quia pecunia illius est.
verses.notes: He is still guilty of the crime, as verse 20 states, but there will not be a financial penalty.

verses.textEn: If men will have quarreled, and one of them has struck a pregnant woman, and as a result she miscarries, but she herself survives, he shall be subject to as much damage as the husband of the woman shall petition from him, or as arbitrators shall judge.
verses.textLa: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit quis mulierem prægnantem, et abortivum quidem fecerit, sed ipsa vixerit: subiacebit damno quantum maritus mulieris expetierit, et arbitri iudicaverint.

verses.textEn: But if her death will have followed, he will repay a life for a life,
verses.textLa: Sin autem mors eius fuerit subsecuta, reddet animam pro anima,

verses.textEn: an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot,
verses.textLa: oculum pro oculo, dentem pro dente, manum pro manu, pedem pro pede,

verses.textEn: a scrape for a scrape, a wound for a wound, a bruise for a bruise.
verses.textLa: adustionem pro adustione, vulnus pro vulnere, livorem pro livore.

verses.textEn: If anyone will have struck the eye of his male or female servant, having left them with one eye, he shall release them freely, because of the eye that he has put out.
verses.textLa: Si percusserit quispiam oculum servi sui aut ancillæ, et luscos eos fecerit, dimittet eos liberos pro oculo quem eruit.

verses.textEn: Likewise, if he knocks out a tooth of his male or female servant, he shall similarly release them freely.
verses.textLa: Dentem quoque si excusserit servo vel ancillæ suæ, similiter dimittet eos liberos.

verses.textEn: If an ox has struck a man or a woman with his horn, and if they die, it shall be stoned. And its flesh shall not be eaten; also, the owner of the ox will be innocent.
verses.textLa: Si bos cornu percusserit virum aut mulierem, et mortui fuerint, lapidibus obruetur: et non comedentur carnes eius, dominus quoque bovis innocens erit.

verses.textEn: But if the ox had been pushing with his horn, from yesterday and the day before, and they warned his owner, but he did not confine it, and it will have killed a man or a woman, then the ox shall be stoned, and his owner shall be killed.
verses.textLa: Quod si bos cornupeta fuerit ab heri et nudiustertius, et contestati sunt dominum eius, nec recluserit eum, occideritque virum aut mulierem: et bos lapidibus obruetur, et dominum eius occident.

verses.textEn: But if they have imposed a price on him, he shall give, in exchange for his life, whatever is asked.
verses.textLa: Quod si pretium fuerit ei impositum, dabit pro anima sua quidquid fuerit postulatus.

verses.textEn: Likewise, if it has struck a son or a daughter with its horns, it shall be subject to a similar verdict.
verses.textLa: Filium quoque et filiam si cornu percusserit, simili sententiæ subiacebit.

verses.textEn: If it attacks a male or female servant, he shall give thirty shekels of silver to their lord, yet truly the ox shall be stoned.
verses.textLa: Si servum, ancillamque invaserit, triginta siclos argenti domino dabit, bos vero lapidibus opprimetur.

verses.textEn: If a man digs or opens a cistern, and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
verses.textLa: Si quis aperuerit cisternam, et foderit, et non operuerit eam, cecideritque bos aut asinus in eam,

verses.textEn: then the owner of the cistern shall repay the price of the beasts, and what is dead will belong to him.
verses.textLa: reddet dominus cisternæ pretium iumentorum: quod autem mortuum est, ipsius erit.

verses.textEn: If the ox of a stranger wounds the ox of another, and it has died, then they shall sell the live ox and divide the price, but the carcass of the dead one they shall distribute between them.
verses.textLa: Si bos alienus bovem alterius vulneraverit, et ille mortuus fuerit: vendent bovem vivum, et divident pretium, cadaver autem mortui inter se dispertient.

verses.textEn: But if he knew that his ox had pushed with its horns, yesterday and the day before, and its owner did not confine it, then he shall repay an ox for an ox, and he will receive the whole carcass.”
verses.textLa: Sin autem sciebat quod bos cornupeta esset ab heri et nudiustertius, et non custodivit eum dominus suus: reddet bovem pro bove, et cadaver integrum accipiet.

verses.textEn: “If anyone will have stolen an ox or a sheep, and if he kills it or sells it, then he will restore five oxen for one ox, and four sheep for one sheep.
verses.textLa: Si quis furatus fuerit bovem, aut ovem, et occiderit vel vendiderit: quinque boves pro uno bove restituet, et quattuor oves pro una ove.

verses.textEn: If a thief will have been discovered breaking into a house, or digging under it, and he has received a mortal wound, he who struck him down will not be guilty of blood.
verses.textLa: Si effringens fur domum sive suffodiens fuerit inventus, et accepto vulnere mortuus fuerit: percussor non erit reus sanguinis.

verses.textEn: But if he did this when the sun was risen, he has perpetrated a homicide, and he shall die. If he does not have the means to make restitution for the theft, he shall be sold.
verses.textLa: Quod si orto sole hoc fecerit, homicidium perpetravit, et ipse morietur. Si non habuerit quod pro furto reddat, ipse venundabitur.

verses.textEn: If whatever he stole should be found with him, a living thing, either an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, he shall repay double.
verses.textLa: Si inventum fuerit apud eum quod furatus est, vivens, sive bos, sive asinus, sive ovis: duplum restituet.

verses.textEn: If there is any damage to a field or a vineyard, when he has released his cattle to pasture on the land of a stranger, he shall repay the best of what he has in his own field, or in his own vineyard, according to the estimation of the damage.
verses.textLa: Si læserit quispiam agrum vel vineam, et dimiserit iumentum suum ut depascatur aliena: quidquid optimum habuerit in agro suo, vel in vinea, pro damni æstimatione restituet.

verses.textEn: If a fire will have been discovered departing from brush, and taking hold in stacks of grain, or in crops standing in the fields, whoever ignited the fire shall repay the damages.
verses.textLa: Si egressus ignis invenerit spinas, et comprehenderit acervos frugum, sive stantes segetes in agris, reddet damnum qui ignem succenderit.

verses.textEn: If anyone will have entrusted money, or a container, to his friend to keep, and if these have been stolen from the one who received them: if the thief is found, he shall repay double.
verses.textLa: Si quis commendaverit amico pecuniam, aut vas in custodiam, et ab eo, qui susceperat, furto ablata fuerint: si invenitur fur, duplum reddet:

verses.textEn: If the thief is unknown, the lord of the house will be brought before the heavens to swear that he did not lay his hand on the goods of his neighbor,
verses.textLa: si latet fur, dominus domus applicabitur ad deos, et iurabit quod non extenderit manum in rem proximi sui,

verses.textEn: so as to perpetrate any fraud, such as with an ox, or a donkey, or a sheep, or clothing, nor to do anything that would be able to cause damage. The case of both shall be brought before the heavens. And if they give judgment against him, he shall repay double to his neighbor.
verses.textLa: ad perpetrandam fraudem, tam in bove, quam in asino, et ove ac vestimento, et quidquid damnum inferre potest: ad deos utriusque causa perveniet: et si illi iudicaverit, duplum restituet proximo suo.

verses.textEn: If anyone will have entrusted a donkey, an ox, a sheep, or any animal to the keeping of his neighbor, and it will have died, or become disabled, or have been captured by enemies, and no one saw it,
verses.textLa: Si quis commendaverit proximo suo asinum, bovem, ovem, et omne iumentum ad custodiam, et mortuum fuerit, aut debilitatum, vel captum ab hostibus, nullusque hoc viderit:

verses.textEn: then there shall be an oath between them, that he did not lay his hand on the goods of his neighbor. And the owner shall accept the oath, and he will not be compelled to make restitution.
verses.textLa: iusiurandum erit in medio, quod non extenderit manum ad rem proximi sui: suscipietque dominus iuramentum, et ille reddere non cogetur.

verses.textEn: But if it will have been taken away by theft, he shall repay the damages to the owner.
verses.textLa: Quod si furto ablatum fuerit, restituet damnum domino.

verses.textEn: If it has been eaten by a wild beast, let him carry what was killed to him, and then he shall not make restitution.
verses.textLa: Si comestum a bestia, deferat ad eum quod occisum est, et non restituet.

verses.textEn: If anyone borrows from his neighbor any of these things, and it has died or been disabled when the owner was not present, he shall be compelled to make restitution.
verses.textLa: Qui a proximo suo quidquam horum mutuo postulaverit, et debilitatum aut mortuum fuerit domino non præsente, reddere compelletur.

verses.textEn: But if the owner was present, he shall not make restitution, especially if it had been brought for hired work.
verses.textLa: Quod si impræsentiarum dominus fuerit, non restituet, maxime si conductum venerat pro mercede operis sui.

verses.textEn: If a man has led astray a virgin not yet betrothed, and he has slept with her, he shall pay her dowry and have her as a wife.
verses.textLa: Si seduxerit quis virginem necdum desponsatam, dormieritque cum ea: dotabit eam, et habebit eam uxorem.

verses.textEn: If the father of the virgin is not willing to give her, he shall pay money according to manner of a dowry, which virgins are accustomed to receive.
verses.textLa: Si pater virginis dare noluerit, reddet pecuniam iuxta modum dotis, quam virgines accipere consueverunt.

verses.textEn: You shall not permit practitioners of the black arts to live.
verses.textLa: Maleficos non patieris vivere.
verses.notes: In Latin, the word ‘maleficos’ means ‘evil doers’. But the Hebrew text is more specific, refering to one who engages in religious or pagan or occult practices for the purpose of doing evil. The Latin word is masculine plural, but the Hebrew work is feminine singular, leading some translation to phrase it as "witch" or "sorceress".

verses.textEn: Whoever has sexual intercourse with an animal shall be put to death.
verses.textLa: Qui coierit cum iumento, morte moriatur.

verses.textEn: Whoever immolates to gods, other than to the Lord, shall be killed.
verses.textLa: Qui immolat diis, occidetur, præterquam Domino soli.

verses.textEn: You shall not harass the newcomer, nor shall you afflict him. For you yourselves were once newcomers in the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Advenam non contristabis, neque affliges eum: advenæ enim et ipsi fuistis in Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: You shall not harm a widow or an orphan.
verses.textLa: Viduæ et pupillo non nocebitis.

verses.textEn: If you hurt them, they will cry out to me, and I will hear their cry.
verses.textLa: Si læseritis eos, vociferabuntur ad me, et ego audiam clamorem eorum:

verses.textEn: And my fury will be enraged, and I will strike you down with the sword. And your wives will become widows, and your sons will become orphans.
verses.textLa: et indignabitur furor meus, percutiamque vos gladio, et erunt uxores vestræ viduæ, et filii vestri pupilli.

verses.textEn: If you lend money to the poor of my people who live among you, you shall not coerce them like a collector, nor oppress them with usury.
verses.textLa: Si pecuniam mutuam dederis populo meo pauperi qui habitat tecum, non urgebis eum quasi exactor, nec usuris opprimes.

verses.textEn: If you take a garment from your neighbor as a pledge, you shall return it to him again before the setting of the sun.
verses.textLa: Si pignus a proximo tuo acceperis vestimentum, ante solis occasum reddes ei.

verses.textEn: For it is all that he has to cover himself, to clothe his body; nor does he have anything else in which to sleep. If he cries out to me, I will hear him, because I am compassionate.
verses.textLa: Ipsum enim est solum, quo operitur, indumentum carnis eius, nec habet aliud in quo dormiat: si clamaverit ad me, exaudiam eum, quia misericors sum.

verses.textEn: You shall not disparage the heavens, and you shall not speak evil of the leader of your people.
verses.textLa: Diis non detrahes, et principi populi tui non maledices.

verses.textEn: You shall not delay in paying your tithes and your first-fruits. You shall give the firstborn of your sons to me.
verses.textLa: Decimas tuas et primitias tuas non tardabis reddere, primogenitum filiorum tuorum dabis mihi.

verses.textEn: You shall do likewise with those of the oxen and the sheep. For seven days, let it be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall repay it to me.
verses.textLa: De bobus quoque, et ovibus similiter facies: septem diebus sit cum matre sua, die octava reddes illum mihi.

verses.textEn: You shall be holy men for me. The flesh, from which beasts will have tasted, you shall not eat, but you will throw it to the dogs.”
verses.textLa: Viri sancti eritis mihi: carnem, quæ a bestiis fuerit prægustata, non comedetis, sed proiicietis canibus.

verses.textEn: “You shall not accept a lying voice. Neither shall you join your hand so as to give false testimony on behalf of the impious.
verses.textLa: Non suscipies vocem mendacii: nec iunges manum tuam ut pro impio dicas falsum testimonium.

verses.textEn: You shall not follow the crowd in doing evil. Neither shall you go astray in judgment, by agreeing with the majority opinion, apart from the truth.
verses.textLa: Non sequeris turbam ad faciendum malum: nec in iudicio, plurimorum acquiesces sententiæ, ut a vero devies.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you shall not show pity in judgment of the poor.
verses.textLa: Pauperis quoque non misereberis in iudicio.

verses.textEn: If you come across an ox or a donkey of your enemy, which has gone astray, lead it back to him.
verses.textLa: Si occurreris bovi inimici tui, aut asino erranti, reduc ad eum.

verses.textEn: If you see the donkey of one who hates you, fallen under its burden, you shall not pass by without lifting it up with him.
verses.textLa: Si videris asinum odientis te iacere sub onere, non pertransibis, sed sublevabis cum eo.

verses.textEn: You shall not deviate in judgment of the poor.
verses.textLa: Non declinabis in iudicium pauperis.

verses.textEn: You shall flee from lies. The innocent and the just you shall not kill. For I shun the impious.
verses.textLa: Mendacium fugies. Insontem et iustum non occides: quia aversor impium.

verses.textEn: Neither shall you accept bribes, which blind even the prudent and subvert the words of the just.
verses.textLa: Nec accipies munera, quæ etiam excæcant prudentes, et subvertunt verba iustorum.

verses.textEn: You shall not harass a sojourner, for you know the life of a newcomer. For you yourselves also were sojourners in the land of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Peregrino molestus non eris. Scitis enim advenarum animas: quia et ipsi peregrini fuistis in Terra Ægypti.

verses.textEn: For six years, you shall sow your land and gather its produce.
verses.textLa: Sex annis seminabis terram tuam, et congregabis fruges eius.

verses.textEn: But in the seventh year, you shall release it and cause it to rest, so that the poor of your people may eat. And whatever remains, let the beasts of the field eat it. So shall you do with your vineyard and your olive grove.
verses.textLa: Anno autem septimo dimittes eam, et requiescere facies, ut comedant pauperes populi tui: et quidquid reliquum fuerit, edant bestiæ agri: ita facies in vinea et in oliveto tuo.

verses.textEn: For six days, you shall work. On the seventh day, you shall cease, so that your ox and your donkey may rest, and so that the newcomer and the son of your handmaid may be refreshed.
verses.textLa: Sex diebus operaberis: septimo die cessabis, ut requiescat bos et asinus tuus: et refrigeretur filius ancillæ tuæ, et advena.

verses.textEn: Preserve all that I have said to you. And by the names of foreign gods you shall not swear; neither shall these be heard from your mouth.
verses.textLa: Omnia quæ dixi vobis, custodite. Et per nomen externorum deorum non iurabitis, neque audietur ex ore vestro.

verses.textEn: Three times in each year, you shall celebrate feasts to me.
verses.textLa: Tribus vicibus per singulos annos mihi festa celebrabitis.

verses.textEn: You shall keep the solemnity of unleavened bread. For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, just as I instructed you, at the time of the month of new grain, when you departed from Egypt. You shall not appear empty-handed in my sight,
verses.textLa: Sollemnitatem azymorum custodies. Septem diebus comedes azyma, sicut præcepi tibi, tempore mensis novorum, quando egressus es de Ægypto: non apparebis in conspectu meo vacuus.

verses.textEn: for it is the solemnity of the harvest of the first-fruits of your work, of whatever you have sown in the field. Likewise, it is a solemnity at the end of the season, when you will have gathered in all your crops from the field.
verses.textLa: Et sollemnitatem messis primitivorum operis tui, quæcumque seminaveris in agro. Sollemnitatem quoque in exitu anni, quando congregaveris omnes fruges tuas de agro.

verses.textEn: Three times a year, all your males shall appear before the Lord your God.
verses.textLa: Ter in anno apparebit omne masculinum tuum coram Domino Deo tuo.

verses.textEn: You shall not immolate the blood of my victim over leaven, nor shall the fat of my solemnity remain until morning.
verses.textLa: Non immolabis super fermento sanguinem victimæ meæ, nec remanebit adeps sollemnitatis meæ usque mane.

verses.textEn: You shall carry the first grain of the land to the house of the Lord your God. You shall not cook a young goat in the milk of its mother.
verses.textLa: Primitias frugum terræ tuæ deferes in domum Domini Dei tui. Non coques hœdum in lacte matris suæ.

verses.textEn: Behold, I will send my Angel, who will go before you, and preserve you on your journey, and lead you into the place that I have prepared.
verses.textLa: Ecce ego mittam Angelum meum, qui præcedat te, et custodiat in via, et introducat in locum quem paravi.

verses.textEn: Heed him, and hear his voice, and do not hold him in disregard. For he will not release you when you have sinned, and my name is in him.
verses.textLa: Observa eum, et audi vocem eius, nec contemnendum putes: quia non dimittet cum peccaveris, et est nomen meum in illo.

verses.textEn: But if you listen to his voice and do all that I say, I will be an enemy to your enemies, and I will afflict those who afflict you.
verses.textLa: Quod si audieris vocem eius, et feceris omnia quæ loquor, inimicus ero inimicis tuis, et affligam affligentes te.

verses.textEn: And my Angel will go before you, and he will bring you to the Amorite, and the Hittite, and the Perizzite, and the Canaanite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite, whom I will crush.
verses.textLa: Præcedetque te Angelus meus, et introducet te ad Amorrhæum, et Hethæum, et Pherezæum, Chananæumque, et Hevæum, et Iebusæum, quos ego conteram.

verses.textEn: You shall not adore their gods, nor worship them. You shall not do their works, but you shall destroy them and break apart their statues.
verses.textLa: Non adorabis deos eorum, nec coles eos: non facies opera eorum, sed destrues eos, et confringes statuas eorum.

verses.textEn: And you shall serve the Lord your God, so that I may bless your bread and your waters, and so that I may take away sickness from your midst.
verses.textLa: Servietisque Domino Deo vestro, ut benedicam panibus tuis et aquis, et auferam infirmitatem de medio tui.

verses.textEn: There will not be fruitless or barren ones in your land. I will fill up the number of your days.
verses.textLa: Non erit infœcunda, nec sterilis in terra tua: numerum dierum tuorum implebo.

verses.textEn: I will send my terror to run ahead of you, and I will kill all the people to whom you will enter. And I will turn the backs of all your enemies before you,
verses.textLa: Terrorem meum mittam in præcursum tuum, et occidam omnem populum, ad quem ingredieris: cunctorumque inimicorum tuorum coram te terga vertam:

verses.textEn: sending wasps ahead, so that they will put to flight the Hivite, and the Canaanite, and the Hittite, before you enter.
verses.textLa: emittens crabrones prius, qui fugabunt Hevæum, et Chananæum, et Hethæum, antequam introeas.

verses.textEn: I will not cast them out from your face in one year, lest the land be reduced to a wilderness and the wild beasts increase against you.
verses.textLa: Non eiiciam eos a facie tua anno uno: ne terra in solitudinem redigatur, et crescant contra te bestiæ.

verses.textEn: I will expel them little by little from your sight, until you have expanded and may possess the land.
verses.textLa: Paulatim expellam eos de conspectu tuo, donec augearis, et possideas Terram.

verses.textEn: Then I will set your limits to be from the Red Sea to the Sea of the Palestinians, and from the desert all the way to the river. I will deliver into your hands the inhabitants of the land, and I will cast them out from your sight.
verses.textLa: Ponam autem terminos tuos a Mari Rubro usque ad Mare Palæstinorum, et a deserto usque ad fluvium: tradam in manibus vestris habitatores Terræ, et eiiciam eos de conspectu vestro.

verses.textEn: You shall not enter into a pact with them, nor with their gods.
verses.textLa: Non inibis cum eis fœdus, nec cum diis eorum.

verses.textEn: They may not live on your land, lest perhaps they may cause you to sin against me, if you serve their gods, which certainly would be a temptation for you.”
verses.textLa: Non habitent in terra tua, ne forte peccare te faciant in me, si servieris diis eorum: quod tibi certe erit in scandalum.

verses.textEn: He also said to Moses: “Ascend to the Lord, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy elders out of Israel, and adore from a distance.
verses.textLa: Moysi quoque dixit: Ascende ad Dominum tu, et Aaron, Nadab, et Abiu, et septuaginta senes ex Israel, et adorabitis procul.

verses.textEn: And only Moses will ascend to the Lord, and these shall not approach. Neither shall the people ascend with him.”
verses.textLa: Solusque Moyses ascendet ad Dominum, et illi non appropinquabunt: nec populus ascendet cum eo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Moses went and explained to the people all the words of the Lord, as well as the judgments. And all the people responded with one voice: “We will do all the words of the Lord, which he has spoken.”
verses.textLa: Venit ergo Moyses et narravit plebi omnia verba Domini, atque iudicia: responditque omnis populus una voce: Omnia verba Domini, quæ locutus est, faciemus.

verses.textEn: Then Moses wrote all the words of the Lord. And rising up in the morning, he built an altar at the base of the mountain, with twelve titles according to the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.textLa: Scripsit autem Moyses universos sermones Domini: et mane consurgens ædificavit altare ad radices montis, et duodecim titulos per duodecim tribus Israel.

verses.textEn: And he sent youths from the sons of Israel, and they offered holocausts, and they immolated calves as peace-offerings to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Misitque iuvenes de filiis Israel, et obtulerunt holocausta, immolaveruntque victimas pacificas Domino, vitulos.

verses.textEn: And so Moses took one half part of the blood, and he put it into bowls. Then the remaining part he poured over the altar.
verses.textLa: Tulit itaque Moyses dimidiam partem sanguinis, et misit in crateras: partem autem residuam fudit super altare.

verses.textEn: And taking up the book of the covenant, he read it in the hearing of the people, who said: “All that the Lord has spoken, we will do, and we will be obedient.”
verses.textLa: Assumensque volumen fœderis, legit audiente populo: qui dixerunt: Omnia quæ locutus est Dominus, faciemus, et erimus obedientes.

verses.textEn: In truth, taking up the blood, he sprinkled it on the people, and he said, “This is the blood of the covenant, which the Lord has formed with you concerning all these words.”
verses.textLa: Ille vero sumptum sanguinem respersit in populum, et ait: Hic est sanguis fœderis quod pepigit Dominus vobiscum super cunctis sermonibus his.

verses.textEn: And Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel ascended.
verses.textLa: Ascenderuntque Moyses et Aaron, Nadab et Abiu, et septuaginta de senioribus Israel:

verses.textEn: And they saw the God of Israel. And under his feet was something like a work of sapphire stone, or like the sky, when it is serene.
verses.textLa: et viderunt Deum Israel: et sub pedibus eius quasi opus lapidis sapphirini, et quasi cælum, cum serenum est.

verses.textEn: Neither did he lay his hand upon those of the sons of Israel who were at a distance. And they saw God, and they ate and drank.
verses.textLa: Nec super eos qui procul recesserant de filiis Israel, misit manum suam, videruntque Deum, et comederunt, ac biberunt.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Ascend to me on the mountain, and be there. And I will give to you tablets of stone, and the law and the commandments that I have written. So may you teach them.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Ascende ad me in montem, et esto ibi: daboque tibi tabulas lapideas, et legem ac mandata quæ scripsi: ut doceas eos.

verses.textEn: Moses rose up, with Joshua his minister. And Moses, ascending on the mountain of God,
verses.textLa: Surrexerunt Moyses et Iosue minister eius: ascendensque Moyses in montem Dei,

verses.textEn: said to the elders: “Wait here, until we return to you. You have Aaron and Hur with you. If any question arises, you shall refer it to them.”
verses.textLa: senioribus ait: Expectate hic donec revertamur ad vos. Habetis Aaron et Hur vobiscum: si quid natum fuerit quæstionis, referetis ad eos.

verses.textEn: And when Moses had ascended, a cloud covered the mountain.
verses.textLa: Cumque ascendisset Moyses, operuit nubes montem.

verses.textEn: And the glory of the Lord dwelt upon Sinai, covering it with a cloud for six days. And on the seventh day, he called to him from the middle of the mist.
verses.textLa: Et habitavit gloria Domini super Sinai, tegens illum nube sex diebus: septimo autem die vocavit eum de medio caliginis.

verses.textEn: Now the appearance of the glory of the Lord was like a burning fire over the summit of the mountain in the sight of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Erat autem species gloriæ Domini, quasi ignis ardens super verticem montis in conspectu filiorum Israel.

verses.textEn: And Moses, entering into the midst of the cloud, ascended the mountain. And he was there for forty days and forty nights.
verses.textLa: Ingressusque Moyses medium nebulæ, ascendit in montem: et fuit ibi quadraginta diebus, et quadraginta noctibus.
verses.notes: The expression ‘forty days and forty nights’ is not an approximate length of time. Whenever the reference is to ‘days and nights,’ the length of time is being presented as an exact length of time. The interpretation may be figurative, but the grammatical meaning is an exact length of time.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel, so that they may take the first-fruits to me. You shall accept these from every man who offers of his own accord.
verses.textLa: Loquere filiis Israel ut tollant mihi primitias ab omni homine qui offeret ultroneus, accipietis eas.

verses.textEn: Now these are the things that you must accept: Gold, and silver, and brass,
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt autem quæ accipere debeatis: Aurum, et argentum, et æs,

verses.textEn: hyacinth and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine linen, the hair of goats,
verses.textLa: hyacinthum et purpuram, coccumque bis tinctum, et byssum, pilos caprarum,

verses.textEn: and the skins of rams, dyed red, and skins of violet, and setim wood,
verses.textLa: et pelles arietum rubricatas, pellesque ianthinas, et ligna setim:

verses.textEn: oil to prepare lights, aromatics as ointments and sweet-smelling incense,
verses.textLa: oleum ad luminaria concinnanda: aromata in unguentum, et thymiamata boni odoris:

verses.textEn: onyx stones and gems to adorn the ephod as well as the breastplate.
verses.textLa: lapides onychinos, et gemmas ad ornandum ephod, ac rationale.

verses.textEn: And they shall make a sanctuary for me, and I will live in their midst.
verses.textLa: Facientque mihi sanctuarium, et habitabo in medio eorum:

verses.textEn: According to exact likeness of the tabernacle, and all of the vessels for its rituals, that I will reveal to you, so shall you make it.
verses.textLa: iuxta omnem similitudinem tabernaculi quod ostendam tibi, et omnium vasorum in cultum eius: sicque facietis illud:

verses.textEn: Join together an ark of setim wood, whose length shall hold two and one half cubits; the width, one and one half cubits; the height, likewise, one and one half cubits.
verses.textLa: Arcam de lignis setim compingite, cuius longitudo habeat duos et semis cubitos: latitudo, cubitum et dimidium: altitudo, cubitum similiter ac semissem.

verses.textEn: And you shall overlay it with the finest gold, inside and out. And over it, you shall fashion a gold crown all around,
verses.textLa: Et deaurabis eam auro mundissimo intus et foris: faciesque supra, coronam auream per circuitum:

verses.textEn: and four gold rings, which you shall set into the four corners of the ark. Let two rings be on one side and two on the other.
verses.textLa: et quattuor circulos aureos, quos pones per quattuor arcæ angulos: duo circuli sint in latere uno, et duo in altero.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you shall make bars of setim wood and cover them with gold.
verses.textLa: Facies quoque vectes de lignis setim, et operies eos auro.

verses.textEn: And you shall put them through the rings that are in the sides of the ark, so that it may be carried on them.
verses.textLa: Inducesque per circulos qui sunt in arcæ lateribus, ut portetur in eis:

verses.textEn: These must always be in the rings, neither shall they ever be drawn out of them.
verses.textLa: qui semper erunt in circulis, nec umquam extrahentur ab eis.

verses.textEn: And you shall place the testimony, which I will give to you, in the ark.
verses.textLa: Ponesque in arca testificationem quam dabo tibi.

verses.textEn: You shall also make a propitiatory of the finest gold. Its length shall hold two and one half cubits, and the width, one and one half cubits.
verses.textLa: Facies et propitiatorium de auro mundissimo: duos cubitos et dimidium tenebit longitudo eius, et cubitum ac semissem latitudo.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you shall make two Cherubim of formed gold, on both sides of the oracle.
verses.textLa: Duos quoque Cherubim aureos et productiles facies, ex utraque parte oraculi.

verses.textEn: Let one Cherub be on the one side, and the other be on the other.
verses.textLa: Cherub unus sit in latere uno, et alter in altero.

verses.textEn: And let them cover both sides of the propitiatory, spreading their wings and covering the oracle, and let them look out toward one another, their faces being turned toward the propitiatory, with which the ark is to be covered,
verses.textLa: Utrumque latus propitiatorii tegant expandentes alas, et operientes oraculum, respiciantque se mutuo versis vultibus in propitiatorium quo operienda est arca,

verses.textEn: in which you will place the testimony that I will give to you.
verses.textLa: in qua pones testimonium quod dabo tibi.

verses.textEn: From there, I will warn you and speak to you, above the propitiatory and from the middle of the two Cherubim, which will be over the ark of the testimony, about everything that I will command of the sons of Israel through you.
verses.textLa: Inde præcipiam, et loquar ad te supra propitiatorium, ac de medio duorum Cherubim, qui erunt super arcam testimonii, cuncta quæ mandabo per te filiis Israel.

verses.textEn: You shall also make a table of setim wood, having two cubits of length, and one cubit in width, and one cubit and one half cubits in height.
verses.textLa: Facies et mensam de lignis setim, habentem duos cubitos longitudinis, et in latitudine cubitum, et in altitudine cubitum et semissem.

verses.textEn: And you shall overlay it with the purest gold. And you shall make it with a gold lip all around,
verses.textLa: Et inaurabis eam auro purissimo: faciesque illi labium aureum per circuitum,

verses.textEn: and for the lip itself an engraved crown, four fingers high, and above it another little gold crown.
verses.textLa: et ipsi labio coronam interrasilem altam quattuor digitis: et super illam, alteram coronam aureolam.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you shall prepare four gold rings and set them in the four corners of the same table, over each foot.
verses.textLa: Quattuor quoque circulos aureos præparabis, et pones eis in quattuor angulis eiusdem mensæ per singulos pedes.

verses.textEn: Under the crown, there shall be gold rings, so that the bars may be put through them and the table may be carried.
verses.textLa: Subter coronam erunt circuli aurei, ut mittantur vectes per eos, et possit mensa portari.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the bars themselves you shall make of setim wood, and surround them with gold, to lift up the table.
verses.textLa: Ipsos quoque vectes facies de lignis setim, et circumdabis auro ad subvehendam mensam.

verses.textEn: You shall also prepare small cups, as well as bowls, censers, and measuring cups, with which the libations shall be offered, out of the purest gold.
verses.textLa: Parabis et acetabula, ac phialas, thuribula, et cyathos, in quibus offerenda sunt libamina, ex auro purissimo.

verses.textEn: And you shall place upon the table the bread of the presence, in my sight always.
verses.textLa: Et pones super mensam panes propositionis in conspectu meo semper.

verses.textEn: You shall also make a lampstand, formed from the finest gold, along with its stem and arms, its bowl and little spheres, as well as the lilies proceeding from it.
verses.textLa: Facies et candelabrum ductile de auro mundissimo, hastile eius, et calamos, scyphos, et sphærulas, ac lilia ex ipso procedentia.

verses.textEn: Six branches shall go out from the sides: three out of one side and three out of the other.
verses.textLa: Sex calami egredientur de lateribus, tres ex uno latere, et tres ex altero.

verses.textEn: Three bowls, the size of nuts, shall be on each branch, and a little sphere with it, and a lily. And three similar bowls, in the likeness of nuts, shall be on the other branch, and a little sphere with it, and a lily. This shall be the form of the six branches, which are to proceed from the stem.
verses.textLa: Tres scyphi quasi in nucis modum per calamos singulos, sphærulaque simul, et lilium: et tres similiter scyphi instar nucis in calamo altero, sphærulaque simul et lilium. Hoc erit opus sex calamorum, qui producendi sunt de hastili:

verses.textEn: Then, in the lampstand itself, there shall be four bowls, the size of nuts, and each with little spheres and lilies.
verses.textLa: in ipso autem candelabro erunt quattuor scyphi in nucis modum, sphærulæque per singulos, et lilia.

verses.textEn: Little spheres under two branches in three places, which together make six, shall proceed from one of the stems.
verses.textLa: Sphærulæ sub duobus calamis per tria loca, qui simul sex fiunt procedentes de hastili uno.

verses.textEn: Thus both the little spheres and the branches shall be made out of the same thing: entirely formed from the purest gold.
verses.textLa: Et sphærulæ igitur et calami ex ipso erunt, universa ductilia de auro purissimo.

verses.textEn: You shall also make seven lamps, and you shall place them upon the lampstand, so that they may give light in every direction.
verses.textLa: Facies et lucernas septem, et pones eas super candelabrum, ut luceant ex adverso.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the candle snuffers, and the place where the candles will be extinguished, shall be made from the purest gold.
verses.textLa: Emunctoria quoque, et ubi quæ emuncta sunt extinguantur, fiant de auro purissimo.

verses.textEn: The entire weight of the candlestick, with all its parts, shall hold one talent of the purest gold.
verses.textLa: Omne pondus candelabri cum universis vasis suis habebit talentum auri purissimi.
verses.notes: A talent is about 30 kilograms or about 66 pounds.

verses.textEn: Observe, and then make it according to the example that was shown to you on the mountain.”
verses.textLa: Inspice, et fac secundum exemplar quod tibi in monte monstratum est.
verses.notes: The instructions for making the candelabra might seem complex and open to varying interpretation, but so, too, is the rest of Scripture.

verses.textEn: “Truly, thus shall you make the tabernacle: You shall make ten curtains of fine twisted linen, and hyacinth as well as purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, with diverse embroidery.
verses.textLa: Tabernaculum vero ita facies: Decem cortinas de bysso retorta, et hyacintho, ac purpura, coccoque bis tincto, variatas opere plumario facies.

verses.textEn: The length of one curtain shall have twenty-eight cubits. The width shall be four cubits. The entire set of curtains shall be of one measure.
verses.textLa: Longitudo cortinæ unius habebit vigintiocto cubitos: latitudo, quattuor cubitorum erit. Unius mensuræ fient universa tentoria.

verses.textEn: Five curtains shall be joined to one another, and the other five shall be similarly coupled together.
verses.textLa: Quinque cortinæ sibi iungentur mutuo, et aliæ quinque nexu simili cohærebunt.

verses.textEn: You shall make loops of hyacinth on the sides at the edges of the curtains, so that they will be able to be joined to one another.
verses.textLa: Ansulas hyacinthinas in lateribus ac summitatibus facies cortinarum, ut possint invicem copulari.

verses.textEn: A curtain shall have fifty loops on each of two sides, inserted in such a manner that loop may come against loop, and one can be fitted to the other.
verses.textLa: Quinquagenas ansulas cortina habebit in utraque parte, ita insertas, ut ansa contra ansam veniat, et altera alteri possit aptari.

verses.textEn: You shall also make fifty rings of gold, with which the veils of the curtains are to be joined, so that it shall be one tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Facies et quinquaginta circulos aureos quibus cortinarum vela iungenda sunt, ut unum tabernaculum fiat.

verses.textEn: You shall also make eleven haircloth canopies to cover the roof of the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Facies et saga cilicina undecim, ad operiendum tectum tabernaculi.

verses.textEn: The length of one canopy shall hold thirty cubits, and the width, four. The measure of all the canopies shall be equal.
verses.textLa: Longitudo sagi unius habebit triginta cubitos: et latitudo, quattuor: æqua erit mensura sagorum omnium.

verses.textEn: Five of these you shall join by themselves, and six of these you shall couple to one another, in such a manner as to double the sixth canopy at the front of the roof.
verses.textLa: E quibus quinque iunges seorsum, et sex sibi mutuo copulabis, ita ut sextum sagum in fronte tecti duplices.
verses.notes: The joints of the joined eleven canopies were staggered (off-set) from the joints of the ten canopies. Thus the seams would not leak rain. Each seam of the ten curtains was covered by the middle of a canopy of the eleven. The canopy hung down further in both the front and the back as a result of the additional length, but it was folded over only in the front.

verses.textEn: You shall also make fifty loops along the edge of one canopy, so that it may be able to be joined with the other, and fifty loops along the edge of the other canopy, so that it may be coupled with the other.
verses.textLa: Facies et quinquaginta ansas in ora sagi unius, ut coniungi cum altero queat: et quinquaginta ansas in ora sagi alterius, ut cum altero copuletur.

verses.textEn: You shall also make fifty brass buckles, with which the loops may be joined, so that there may be one covering out of all.
verses.textLa: Facies et quinquaginta fibulas æneas, quibus iungantur ansæ, ut unum ex omnibus operimentum fiat.
verses.notes: The buckles are different method of attaching the loops than the rings. Using different methods of attachment, and different materials, one over another, provides greater strength and reliability in building anything.

verses.textEn: Then what will be left over of the canopies which are prepared for the roof, that is, one canopy which is in excess, from half of it you shall cover the back of the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Quod autem superfuerit in sagis quæ parantur tecto, id est, unum sagum quod amplius est, ex medietate eius operies posteriora tabernaculi.

verses.textEn: And one cubit will hang down on one side, and another on the other side, which is more than the length of the curtains, protecting both sides of the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Et cubitus ex una parte pendebit, et alter ex altera qui plus est in sagorum longitudine, utrumque latus tabernaculi protegens.
verses.notes: Here we learn that the ‘doubled’ canopy is not literally doubled in half, but folded so that one cubit of additional length is given to the overhang. This must have been folded toward the inside, rather than the outside, so that the fold would not collect rain.

verses.textEn: You shall also make another covering for the roof from the skins of rams, dyed-red, and above that again, another covering of violet-colored skins.
verses.textLa: Facies et operimentum aliud tecto de pellibus arietum rubricatis: et super hoc rursum aliud operimentum de ianthinis pellibus.
verses.notes: It is unclear from which animal these violet-colored skins came.

verses.textEn: You shall also make the standing panels of the tabernacle from setim wood.
verses.textLa: Facies et tabulas stantes tabernaculi de lignis setim,

verses.textEn: Of these, each shall have ten cubits in length, and in width, one and one half.
verses.textLa: quæ singulæ denos cubitos in longitudine habeant, et in latitudine singulos ac semissem.

verses.textEn: At the sides of the panels, there shall be made two dovetails, by which one panel may be connected to another panel; and in this way all the panels shall be prepared.
verses.textLa: In lateribus tabulæ, duæ incastraturæ fient, quibus tabula alteri tabulæ connectatur: atque in hunc modum cunctæ tabulæ parabuntur.

verses.textEn: Of these, twenty shall be at the meridian, which lies toward the south.
verses.textLa: Quarum viginti erunt in latere meridiano quod vergit ad Austrum.

verses.textEn: For these, you shall cast forty bases of silver, so that two bases will lie under each panel at its two corners.
verses.textLa: Quibus quadraginta bases argenteas fundes, ut binæ bases singulis tabulis per duos angulos subiiciantur.

verses.textEn: Likewise, at the second side of the tabernacle, which lies to the north, there shall be twenty panels,
verses.textLa: In latere quoque secundo tabernaculi quod vergit ad Aquilonem, viginti tabulæ erunt,

verses.textEn: having forty bases of silver; two bases shall support each panel.
verses.textLa: quadraginta habentes bases argenteas: binæ bases singulis tabulis supponentur.

verses.textEn: Truly, toward the western part of the tabernacle, you shall make six panels,
verses.textLa: Ad occidentalem vero plagam tabernaculi facies sex tabulas,

verses.textEn: and again another two, which will be raised at the corners, behind the back of the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: et rursum alias duas quæ in angulis erigantur post tergum tabernaculi.
verses.notes: The raised corners made the Tabernacle asymmetrical, so that the back corners were the highest part of the tent.

verses.textEn: And these shall be joined together from bottom to top, and one joint shall retain them all. Likewise, two of the panels, which will be set at the corners, shall be served by similar joints.
verses.textLa: Eruntque coniunctæ a deorsum usque sursum, et una omnes compago retinebit. Duabus quoque tabulis quæ in angulis ponendæ sunt, similis iunctura servabitur.

verses.textEn: And together these will be eight panels, and their bases of silver, sixteen, counting two bases for each panel.
verses.textLa: Et erunt simul tabulæ octo, bases earum argenteæ sedecim, duabus basibus per unam tabulam supputatis.
verses.notes: The west side had 8 panels, but the east only had 6, because the east end had the two panel (three royal cubit) opening for the width of the entrance. This entrance width of just under 5 feet, 2 inches, was needed to allow two men to enter side by side, carrying the ark and the tables for the Sanctuary.

verses.textEn: You shall also make five bars of setim wood, to connect the panels on one side of the tabernacle,
verses.textLa: Facies et vectes de lignis setim quinque ad continendas tabulas in uno latere tabernaculi,

verses.textEn: and five others on the other side, and the same number toward the western part.
verses.textLa: et quinque alios in altero, et eiusdem numeri ad occidentalem plagam:

verses.textEn: These shall be set along the middle of the panels, from one end all the way to the other end.
verses.textLa: qui mittentur per medias tabulas a summo usque ad summum.
verses.notes: Or, ‘through the middle of the panels.’

verses.textEn: Likewise, the panels themselves you shall overlay with gold, and you shall establish rings of gold in them, by which the bars of the panels may be connected. These you shall cover with layers of gold.
verses.textLa: Ipsas quoque tabulas deaurabis, et fundes in eis annulos aureos per quos vectes tabulata contineant: quos operies laminis aureis.

verses.textEn: And you shall raise the tabernacle according to the example which was shown to you on the mountain.
verses.textLa: Et eriges tabernaculum iuxta exemplar quod tibi in Monte monstratum est.

verses.textEn: You shall also make a veil of hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen, wrought with a diversity of continuous and beautiful embroidery.
verses.textLa: Facies et velum de hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere plumario et pulchra varietate contextum:

verses.textEn: And you shall suspend it before four columns of setim wood, which themselves certainly shall be overlaid with gold, and have heads of gold, but bases of silver.
verses.textLa: quod appendes ante quattuor columnas de lignis setim, quæ ipsæ quidem deauratæ erunt, et habebunt capita aurea, sed bases argenteas.

verses.textEn: Then the veil shall be inserted through the rings. Beyond the veil, you shall place the ark of the testimony, where both the Sanctuary and the Sanctuary of Sanctuaries shall be divided.
verses.textLa: Inseretur autem velum per circulos, intra quod pones arcam testimonii, quo et Sanctuarium, et Sanctuarii sanctuaria dividentur.

verses.textEn: And you shall place the propitiatory over the ark of the testimony, in the Holy of Holies.
verses.textLa: Pones et propitiatorium super arcam testimonii in Sancto sanctorum:

verses.textEn: And the table shall be outside the veil. And opposite the table shall be the lampstand, in the meridian of the tabernacle. For the table shall stand at the north side.
verses.textLa: mensamque extra velum: et contra mensam candelabrum in latere tabernaculi meridiano: mensa enim stabit in parte Aquilonis.

verses.textEn: You shall also make a tent at the entrance of the tabernacle from hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen, wrought with embroidery.
verses.textLa: Facies et tentorium in introitu tabernaculi de hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere plumarii.
verses.notes: This tent was outside of the Tabernacle, forming a covered entryway, which protected the Tabernacle from wind and rain and dust.

verses.textEn: And you shall overlay with gold five columns of setim wood, over which the tent shall be drawn. The heads of these shall be of gold, and the bases of brass.”
verses.textLa: Et quinque columnas deaurabis lignorum setim, ante quas ducetur tentorium: quarum erunt capita aurea, et bases æneæ.

verses.textEn: “You shall also make an altar of setim wood, which will have five cubits in length, and the same in width, that is, four equal sides, and three cubits in height.
verses.textLa: Facies et altare de lignis setim, quod habebit quinque cubitus in longitudine, et totidem in latitudine, id est, quadrum, et tres cubitos in altitudine.

verses.textEn: Now there shall be horns at the four corners of it, and you shall cover it with brass.
verses.textLa: Cornua autem per quattuor angulos ex ipso erunt: et operies illud ære.

verses.textEn: And you shall make, for its uses, pans to receive the ashes, and tongs as well as small hooks, and receptacles for fire. You shall fabricate all of its vessels from brass,
verses.textLa: Faciesque in usus eius lebetes ad suscipiendos cineres, et forcipes atque fuscinulas, et ignium receptacula. Omnia vasa ex ære fabricabis:

verses.textEn: along with a grating of brass in the manner of a net. At its four corners there shall be four rings of brass,
verses.textLa: Craticulamque in modum retis æneam: per cuius quattuor angulos erunt quattuor annuli ænei,

verses.textEn: which you shall place under the base of the altar. And the grating will extend even to the middle of the altar.
verses.textLa: quos pones subter arulam altaris: eritque craticula usque ad altaris medium.

verses.textEn: You shall also make, for the altar, two bars of setim wood, which you shall cover with layers of brass.
verses.textLa: Facies et vectes altaris de lignis setim duos, quos operies laminis æneis:

verses.textEn: And you shall lead them through the rings, and they will be on both sides of the altar to carry it.
verses.textLa: et induces per circulos, eruntque ex utroque latere altaris ad portandum.

verses.textEn: You shall not make it solid, but empty and hollow at the interior, just as it was shown to you on the mountain.
verses.textLa: Non solidum, sed inane et cavum intrinsecus facies illud, sicut tibi in Monte monstratum est.

verses.textEn: You shall also make the atrium of the tabernacle, at the southern part of which, opposite the meridian, there shall be hangings of fine twisted linen: one side extending for one hundred cubits in length.
verses.textLa: Facies et atrium tabernaculi, in cuius australi plaga contra meridiem erunt tentoria de bysso retorta: centum cubitos unum latus tenebit in longitudine.

verses.textEn: And you shall make twenty columns with the same number of bases of brass, the heads of which, with their engravings, shall be made of silver.
verses.textLa: Et columnas viginti cum basibus totidem æneis, quæ capita cum cælaturis suis habebunt argentea.

verses.textEn: In like manner also, throughout the length of the north side, there shall be hangings of one hundred cubits, and twenty columns, and the same number of bases of brass, and their heads with their engravings of silver.
verses.textLa: Similiter et in latere aquilonis per longum erunt tentoria centum cubitorum, columnæ viginti, et bases æneæ eiusdem numeri, et capita earum cum cælaturis suis argentea.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, along the width of the atrium that looks out toward the west, there shall be hangings of fifty cubits, and ten columns, and the same number of bases.
verses.textLa: In latitudine vero atrii, quod respicit ad occidentem, erunt tentoria per quinquaginta cubitos, et columnæ decem, basesque totidem.

verses.textEn: Likewise, along the width of the atrium that looks out toward the east, there shall be fifty cubits,
verses.textLa: In ea quoque atrii latitudine, quæ respicit ad orientem, quinquaginta cubiti erunt,

verses.textEn: along which there shall be assigned hangings of fifteen cubits for one side, and three columns, and the same number of bases.
verses.textLa: in quibus quindecim cubitorum tentoria lateri uno deputabuntur, columnæque tres, et bases totidem:

verses.textEn: And, along the other side, there shall be hangings occupying fifteen cubits, with three columns and the same number of bases.
verses.textLa: et in latere altero erunt tentoria cubitos obtinentia quindecim, columnæ tres, et bases totidem.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, at the entrance of the atrium, there shall be made a hanging of twenty cubits, of hyacinth and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen, wrought with embroidery. It shall have four columns, with the same number of bases.
verses.textLa: In introitu vero atrii fiet tentorium cubitorum viginti ex hyacintho et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere plumarii: columnas habebit quattuor, cum basibus totidem.

verses.textEn: All the columns surrounding the atrium shall be clothed with layers of silver, with silver heads, and with bases of brass.
verses.textLa: Omnes columnæ atrii per circuitum vestitæ erunt argenteis laminis, capitibus argenteis, et basibus æneis.

verses.textEn: In length, the atrium shall occupy one hundred cubits, in width, fifty; the height shall be of five cubits. And it shall be made of fine twisted linen, and it shall have bases of brass.
verses.textLa: In longitudine occupabit atrium cubitos centum, in latitudine quinquaginta, altitudo quinque cubitorum erit: fietque de bysso retorta, et habebit bases æneas.

verses.textEn: All the vessels of the tabernacle, for all uses and ceremonies, even to the tent pegs for its atrium, you shall make of brass.
verses.textLa: Cuncta vasa tabernaculi in omnes usus et ceremonias, tam paxillos eius quam atrii, ex ære facies.

verses.textEn: Instruct the sons of Israel so that they may bring you the purest oil of the olive trees, crushed with a pestle, so that a lamp may always burn
verses.textLa: Præcipe filiis Israel ut afferant tibi oleum de arboribus olivarum purissimum, piloque contusum: ut ardeat lucerna semper

verses.textEn: in the tabernacle of the testimony, outside of the veil that enshrouds the testimony. And Aaron and his sons shall arrange it, so that it may give light in the presence of the Lord, until morning. This shall be a perpetual observance among the sons of Israel, throughout their successions.”
verses.textLa: in tabernaculo testimonii, extra velum quod oppansum est testimonio. Et collocabunt eam Aaron et filii eius, ut usque mane luceat coram Domino. Perpetuus erit cultus per successiones eorum a filiis Israel.

verses.textEn: “Also, join to yourself your brother Aaron, with his sons from the midst of the sons of Israel, so that they may exercise the priesthood for me: Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
verses.textLa: Applica quoque ad te Aaron fratrem tuum cum filiis suis de medio filiorum Israel, ut sacerdotio fungantur mihi: Aaron, Nadab, et Abiu, Eleazar, et Ithamar.

verses.textEn: And you shall make a holy vestment for Aaron, your brother, with glory and elegance.
verses.textLa: Faciesque vestem sanctam Aaron fratri tuo in gloriam et decorem.

verses.textEn: And you shall speak to all the wise of heart, whom I have filled with the spirit of prudence, so that they may make the vestments of Aaron, in which, having been sanctified, he may minister to me.
verses.textLa: Et loqueris cunctis sapientibus corde, quos replevi spiritu prudentiæ, ut faciant vestes Aaron, in quibus sanctificatus ministret mihi.

verses.textEn: Now these shall be the vestments that they shall make: A breastplate and an ephod, a tunic and a close-fit linen garment, a headdress and a wide belt. They shall make the holy vestments for your brother Aaron and his sons, so that they may exercise the priesthood for me.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem erunt vestimenta quæ faciet: Rationale, et superhumerale, tunicam et lineam strictam, cidarim et balteum. Facient vestimenta sancta fratri tuo Aaron et filiis eius, ut sacerdotio fungantur mihi.
verses.notes: The superhumerale or ephod was the ancient predecessor or prefigure of the Catholic scapular.

verses.textEn: And they shall receive gold, and hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine linen.
verses.textLa: Accipientque aurum, et hyacinthum, et purpuram, coccumque bis tinctum, et byssum.

verses.textEn: Then they shall make the ephod of gold, and hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen, wrought with diverse colors.
verses.textLa: Facient autem superhumerale de auro et hyacintho et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere polymito.

verses.textEn: It shall have two edges joined at the top on both sides, so that they may respond as one.
verses.textLa: Duas oras iunctas habebit in utroque latere summitatum, ut in unum redeant.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the weaving and all the detail work shall be of gold, and hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen.
verses.textLa: Ipsa quoque textura et cuncta operis varietas erit ex auro et hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta.

verses.textEn: And you shall take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel:
verses.textLa: Sumesque duos lapides onychinos, et sculpes in eis nomina filiorum Israel:

verses.textEn: six names on one stone, and the remaining six on the other, according to the order of their birth.
verses.textLa: sex nomina in lapide uno, et sex reliqua in altero, iuxta ordinem nativitatis eorum.

verses.textEn: By the work of a sculptor and the skill of a jeweler, you shall engrave them with the names of the sons of Israel, enclosed and encompassed with gold.
verses.textLa: Opere sculptoris et cælatura gemmarii, sculpes eos nominibus filiorum Israel, inclusos auro atque circumdatos:
verses.notes: In this context, the word ‘cælatura’ refers to the process of engraving and the skill by which it is done, not to the engraving itself. Thus the rough work was to be done by a sculptor, but completed (in the finer details of the work) by a jeweler.

verses.textEn: And you shall place them on both sides of the ephod, as a memorial to the sons of Israel. And Aaron shall carry their names before the Lord, upon both shoulders, as a remembrance.
verses.textLa: et pones in utroque latere superhumeralis, memoriale filiis Israel. Portabitque Aaron nomina eorum coram Domino super utrumque humerum, ob recordationem.

verses.textEn: You shall also make hooks of gold,
verses.textLa: Facies et uncinos ex auro,

verses.textEn: and two little chains of the purest gold, linked to one another, which you shall insert into the hooks.
verses.textLa: et duas catenulas ex auro purissimo sibi invicem cohærentes, quas inseres uncinis.

verses.textEn: Likewise, you shall make the breastplate of judgment, wrought with diverse colors according to the weaving of the ephod: of gold, hyacinth and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, and fine twisted linen.
verses.textLa: Rationale quoque iudicii facies opere polymito iuxta texturam superhumeralis ex auro, hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta.

verses.textEn: It shall have four corners and be doubled. It shall have the measure of the palm of a hand, both in length and in width.
verses.textLa: Quadrangulum erit et duplex: mensuram palmi habebit tam in longitudine quam in latitudine.
verses.notes: It starts out as a square, with equal sides, but then it is folded (doubled) to be twice as high as it is wide, having about the proportions and the size of the palm of a hand.

verses.textEn: And you shall set within it four rows of stones. In the first row, there shall be a sardius stone, and a topaz, and an emerald.
verses.textLa: Ponesque in eo quattuor ordines lapidum: in primo versu erit lapis sardius, et topazius, et smaragdus:

verses.textEn: In the second, there shall be a garnet, a sapphire, and a jasper.
verses.textLa: in secundo carbunculus, sapphirus, et iaspis:

verses.textEn: In the third, there shall be a zircon, an agate, and an amethyst.
verses.textLa: in tertio ligurius, achates, et amethystus:

verses.textEn: In the fourth, there shall be a chrysolite, an onyx, and a beryl. They shall be set in gold by their rows.
verses.textLa: in quarto chrysolithus, onychinus, et beryllus. Inclusi auro erunt per ordines suos.

verses.textEn: And these shall have the names of the sons of Israel. With twelve names shall they be engraved: each stone with one name from the twelve tribes.
verses.textLa: Habebuntque nomina filiorum Israel: duodecim nominibus cælabuntur, singuli lapides nominibus singulorum per duodecim tribus.

verses.textEn: You shall make chains of the purest gold, linked one to another, on the breastplate,
verses.textLa: Facies in rationali catenas sibi invicem cohærentes ex auro purissimo:

verses.textEn: and two rings of gold, which you shall place at both ends of the breastplate.
verses.textLa: et duos annulos aureos, quos pones in utraque rationalis summitate:

verses.textEn: And the golden chains, you shall join to the rings, which are at its edges.
verses.textLa: catenasque aureas iunges annulis, qui sunt in marginibus eius:

verses.textEn: And the ends of the chains themselves, you shall couple with two hooks, on both sides of the ephod, which looks toward the breastplate.
verses.textLa: et ipsarum catenarum extrema duobus copulabis uncinis in utroque latere superhumeralis quod rationale respicit.

verses.textEn: You shall also make two rings of gold, which you shall place at the ends of the breastplate, at the borders which are away from the region of the ephod and which look toward its back.
verses.textLa: Facies et duos annulos aureos, quos pones in summitatibus rationalis, in oris, quæ e regione sunt superhumeralis, et posteriora eius aspiciunt.

verses.textEn: And then you shall also make two other rings of gold, which are to be suspended on both sides at the bottom of the ephod, which looks out opposite the face of the lower juncture, so that the breastplate can be fitted to the ephod.
verses.textLa: Nec non et alios duos annulos aureos, qui ponendi sunt in utroque latere superhumeralis deorsum, quod respicit contra faciem iuncturæ inferioris, ut aptari possit cum superhumerali,

verses.textEn: And it shall be drawn tight to the rings of the breastplate, by the rings of the ephod, with a hyacinth band, so that the well-constructed juncture will remain in place, and the breastplate and the ephod will not be able to be separated from one another.
verses.textLa: et stringatur rationale annulis suis cum annulis superhumeralis vitta hyacinthina, ut maneat iunctura fabrefacta, et a seinvicem rationale et superhumerale nequeant separari.

verses.textEn: And Aaron shall carry the names of the sons of Israel on the breastplate of judgment upon his chest, when he enters into the Sanctuary, as a memorial in the presence of the Lord in eternity.
verses.textLa: Portabitque Aaron nomina filiorum Israel in rationali iudicii super pectus suum, quando ingredietur Sanctuarium, memoriale coram Domino in æternum.

verses.textEn: Then you shall place in the breastplate of judgment, Doctrine and Truth, which shall then be upon Aaron’s chest, when he enters before the Lord. And he shall wear the judgment of the sons of Israel on his chest, in the sight of the Lord always.
verses.textLa: Pones autem in rationali iudicii Doctrinam et Veritatem, quæ erunt in pectore Aaron, quando ingredietur coram Domino: et gestabit iudicium filiorum Israel in pectore suo, in conspectu Domini semper.

verses.textEn: And you shall make the tunic for the ephod entirely of hyacinth,
verses.textLa: Facies et tunicam superhumeralis totam hyacinthinam,

verses.textEn: and the head will be above its middle, with a hem woven around it, just as is usually made at the end parts of a garment, so that it may not be easily broken.
verses.textLa: in cuius medio supra erit capitium, et ora per gyrum eius textilis, sicut fieri solet in extremis vestium partibus, ne facile rumpatur.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, beneath it, at the base of the same tunic, all around, you shall make something like pomegranates, from hyacinth, and purple, and twice-dyed scarlet, with little bells set in their midst.
verses.textLa: Deorsum vero, ad pedes eiusdem tunicæ, per circuitum, quasi mala punica facies, ex hyacintho, et purpura, et cocco bis tincto, mistis in medio tintinnabulis,
verses.notes: The phrase ‘mala punica’ refers to ‘apples (or fruits) of Punicia (i.e. Carthage)’. Carthage apples are pomegranates.

verses.textEn: So then, there shall be a little golden bell and a pomegranate, and again another golden bell and a pomegranate.
verses.textLa: ita ut tintinnabulum sit aureum et malum punicum: rursumque tintinnabulum aliud aureum et malum punicum.

verses.textEn: And Aaron will be vested with it during the office of his ministry, so that the sound may be heard when he enters and exits the Sanctuary, in the sight of the Lord, and so that he may not die.
verses.textLa: Et vestietur ea Aaron in officio ministerii, ut audiatur sonitus quando ingreditur et egreditur Sanctuarium in conspectu Domini, et non moriatur.

verses.textEn: And you shall make a plate of the purest gold, in which you shall engrave, with the skill of a sculptor, ‘Holy to the Lord.’
verses.textLa: Facies et laminam de auro purissimo: in qua sculpes opere cælatoris, Sanctum Domino.
